number of helpful: 29 of 53 people (55%) found this review helpful6 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 27, 2015
												E: This review was written a day before the July 28th update.Hello~ as of this review, I've clocked 62 hours on Damned.The reason why I'm giving this game a thumbs down will become apparent quite quick.I'm not going to give overviews, so I apologize in advance if anything sounds off to someone who knows nothing about the game just yet. Simply put, despite how much fun I have with the game, a lot of my friends DON'T have fun, and I'm going to list all of the problems here.1. The insanity system is bogus. E: This has been fixed as of July 28th, about two days after I wrote this review.Seriously. Having so many bad effects happen throughout the game is annoying, and un-needed unless you happen to be playing against Mary (because she moves slow enough to warrant them). Late in a game, survivors see things that aren't there, but still physically affect them, turning them blind, slowing them down, or making them deaf; often all at once. This seriously needs to become an optional thing, but for now, it's extremely crippling to any survivors that manage to last long enough against monsters to begin with.2. Mary's teleporting is bogus. - E: Still a problem, unfortunately.Tonight I've had a game where Mary's teleported into the same general area 5 times, sometimes right next to where she was previously, successfully edging survivors closer to their spawn point with no way to progress. This speaks for herself: Mary's teleportation mechanism is NOT random, but is more biased to teleporting into the same room despite how big a map is, and needs a system countermeasure.3. Phantom's camping is bogus. E: Still a problem, unfortunately.This one speaks for itself. Phantom needs a penalty for staying in one place (sometimes to camp a corpse or deliberately trap survivors) for too long. Otherwise, he's fine. Applies to a lesser extent to the Lurker as well.Those are the three big issues that my friends tend to have with this game. Personally, I've beat the odds and have continued playing despite these major flaws, and can still manage to have fun in the game to this day. And these problems don't even touch the plethora of other problems, such as...- Frequent client crashes- Host disconnecting from a game crashes the game- Connection issues cause duplicates of corpses to walk continuously into walls- Maps such as the factory spawning unwinnable for the survivors due to key placement- Lack of care / content / fixes from the developers (E: As of 1/30/16, it appears as if they've deleted their community forum)So with that being said, I definitely cannot recommend this game, since it's nowhere close to being worth its full $20 pricetag. Know that if you do end up buying this game, whether it's for the full price or on a sale, that you'll be paying lazy developers that are more talk and less action. If you can somehow see past that and can see a glimmer of fun trapped deep within the potential that is Damned, then I shall see you there.Oh, and don't forget. The monsters can kill you in one hit. But I don't have a problem with that. I just want to actually SEE the monster kill me instead of getting blinded before the climax. What kind of a climax is that?E: Having the ability for people to change their usernames was a bad addition, so I'm not going to be changing the recommendation of my review. The game's files are predominately client-sided and can be edited by hackers. Now the hackers in the game can change their names, and we'll never know who we're playing against anymore, so thanks a lot 9heads.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18, 2015
												I was pleasantly surprised by Damned. The gameplay does get repetitive, and eventually you get tired with the constant issue of starting a game, only to have 1 or 2 people disconnect and not be able to join back.The game is fun if you have 4-5 friends to play with. When I say friends, I mean friends you can talk to and communicate with. My friends and I would have the humans all in a group call and then the monster on their own. This made the game pretty damn fun, as we could communicate.The gameplay gets pretty boring after 9-10 hours of playing. You basically run around looking for keys while avoiding the monster. Each monster has different abilities, meaning you have to change your strategy slightly depending on the type of monster. Currently, there are only 3 monsters.The Lurker - The Lurker has a physical and nonphysical form. In its non-physical form, it cannot see players and players cannot see it, but it can place traps. Traps make a loud noise, notifying The Lurker where the humans are. The Lurker can then transform into physical form (if it has enough charged up) and try and kill them.Mary - Mary moves very very slow, and Mary can see humans and humans can see Mary. Mary has the ability to teleport when charged up (also randomly teleporting if you do not for a long time). Mary also slowly gains "Frenzy". Frenzy mode allows Mary to run faster than survivors and kill them. To charge Frenzy, you have to get close to a survivor. The closer you are, the faster it charges up.The Phantom - This one is personally my least favorite. The survivors can see the Phantom at all times, but the Phantom cannot see the humans unless they make a noise. If a survivor begins sprinting, the Phantom will hear loud music and that survivor will be able to be seen through walls. You also can't turn your flashlight on and off when the Phantom is around. Basically, the closer you get to the Phantom, the less sound you have to make, by crouching or walking.Like I said, the gameplay is fun with friends, but over time it loses its luster and becomes very repetitive. I bought it with 4 other friends when it was only $5, and it was definitly worth it. Rarely we got to do 5 player, but 4 player is still really fun.If you can manage to find 3 or 4 friends to play it with, get it on sale. The bugs are pretty irritating, mostly the main menu bugs that require me to verify the integrity of game cache every 30 minutes. But the bugs are also tolerable because the gameplay has its ups for a decent amount of play time.

content:
Posted: October 15, 2014
												This is a pretty under-appreciated multiplayer experience.  You start with up to four survivors and one "Ghost" sort of character, dependant upon the number of players you've brought into the game (2-5 players, one of them playing the monstery threat).  The object of the game for the survivors is to find all the keys and tools they need to pry the boards off of an exit door, unlock it, and leave - which is not easily done.  The goal of the ghost player is, of course, to make sure no one escapes alive.The game has a pretty nice ingame chat system that works into the game.  Some ghosts can hear you when they're near, some ghosts can simply hear you chatting - and the ghost itself can use a built-in voice gimmick that lets them make their voice deeper or higher for creepy effect - this is especially good in multiplayer matches where you want to add an extra element of tension, and is particularly fun when (as the ghost) you manage to be creepy enough to make someone panic.All of the game's baddies play differently.  It's not a difficult game to get to know, and playing around with the ghosts will allow you to uncover how they function pretty swiftly.  This is knowledge that survivor players may or may not have - and not knowing how the enemy ghost functions can be particularly problematic for new players, as they may not know, for example, that the phantom cannot see you until you make noise.If you're a fan of horror games, and you're looking for a fine co-op experience with up to 4 of your friends, this game is a recommended purchase.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
												The first question I ask of you is: do you have friends? If no, then stop right here. You don't need to read anymore. If yes, then the next question is: do you value their friendship? If no, then doh, you rebel, you. If yes, then my very last question is this: do you want to keep them? This game is absolutely terrifying and clearly, is best played with strangers.No, no. I kid... definitely play this game with your friends. Strangers might end up scaring you more. Beg for their mercy if they're playing as one of the four monsters. Beg them to spare you and leave you alone - "take the other person instead!". This is all you can do in Damned. Loyalties will be tested and friendships strained. Expect a few harsh words to come your way from someone whom you once cherised.Can you escape the hellish halls and paths that the cursed walk upon? With just a flashlight and a weak battery, are you strong enough to pervail and, ultimately, survive? If yes.... your adventure awaits...---------------------------------------------------------Pros+ Mary, oh Mary...+ Great game to play with both friends, strangers, and AI's+ Monsters have been updated (Mary is absolutely terrifying now)+ Simple horror game with one objective: escape the house. Very straightforward yet satisfyingly fun+ Sound effects and music play a very important role in this game: they serve to scare you witless+ Honestly one of the most fulfilling horror games that I have played in a very long time; true jump scares are in store for you....Cons- Developer's are not as active as one would like them to be- Some elements are hard to interact with. Maybe it's just my game, but it's difficult to pick up items at times. Furthermore, it can be difficult to open things (very easy to just accidently close something you mean to open)---------------------------------------------------------Damned is definitely one of the best horror games that you could possibly ask for and play with friends. It is unique and refreshing, something that is hard to find within this genre. Your friendship will either strengthen or weaken with this game, so put it through the ultimate test. Can it survive a test from the damned?Overall7/10

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
												This game is a great game to play with friends.  It is very fun being a monster, moreso when you mess with the survivors rather than trying to kill them every chance you get.  Playing as a survivor will get your heart racing and wake your roomates.  The ambiance adds a serious chill to the air as you desperately look for items to aid in the escape, all the while being on your toes looking out for the monster.  Swinging your mouse to open doors and cabinets like the Penumbra games gives you more control, and more chances to make mistakes trying to slam doors on chasing monsters.  Sounds like a game to give a whirl right?Not so fast.You might want to rethink that purchase.  This game is absolutely loaded with problems, mainly with nuances in the design and the framework of the game itself.  Right off the bat, this game is written in Python, meaning you will have to install Python first, however Damned will install Python for you.  After installation you may have to restart your computer to fix any initial problems you run into.  Restarting a machine to get a video game to work is unacceptable in this day and age.  This game is not optimized very well.  High shadows, lighting, or AA will tax some machines more than it should with unremarkable differences in the quality of the graphics.  Connection issues can be spontaneous, and freezing can at some times be common.  This game has moods.  One day it will work relatively fine, the next it won't.  Hope you like verifying your game files, because you will be doing that a lot with this game, and you will almost always find at least one file missing.  Even after reacquiring that missing file your game may still not work properly.  It's not uncommon to spend more time than should be necessary just to get everyone to join the game proper.This game has horrible balancing issues.  The monsters are quite powerful, with some maps making it just downright impossible to win as survivors.  There are no limits to setting traps as the monsters, and there are loads of things that can be trapped.  Many maps have narrow corridors with overhanging lights that can be trapped and impossible to avoid.  Survivors also have no way of knowing what is trapped without springing it.  In order for the survivors to win, they must find the silver key, hammer/crowbar, and the actual escape door, all while avoiding the monster.  The key and tools however are usually behind some locked door which requires some other key to open.  Of course there is no indication of what keys open what, with some levels having many locked doors and you will find yourself running back and forth looking in every nook and cranny for every key you can find and testing them on many doors until you can open one.  Insanity, the condition set upon survivors as the game drags on, is designed to keep survivors moving, but uses cheap jump scares and annoying hands to do the job.  Also darkens the screen or flickers the flashlight sometimes which is actually nice.  The maps are dreary, abandoned, gritty, dark places, a staple of horror.  But they can also be confusing and tedious, especially when trying to find that one key to open that one door.  Of the 11 maps, 3 are in an asylum.  Sometimes items may glitch out and cant be picked up, or cabinet doors that's shouldn't be locked won't open.  There are also jack-o-lanterns all over the place.  Is this a halloween or horror game?Even after all this, I would still recommend the game if not for one thing:  The asking price.  $20 USD is highway robbery for a game in as bad a state as this.  Maybe the developers believe they put in effort worthy of selling for $20.  I don't see it.Buy this game?  No.  Sit on it.

It's the quality I expect from a beta or Early Access game.

Early Access Review
								I would love to recommend this game, but I cannot. It has a brilliant premise, and is very creepy with it's stalking monsters and malicious spirits. But it has several catastrophic problems that render it next to unplayable. It is incredibly laggy (and not to do with my connection, which is ultra-fast on all other things I do) and suffers from FPS stuttering to quite a bad degree. Sometimes when survivors die a copy of them stays around, walking endlessly on the air until they are killed as well, leaving two corpses. It has other weird, glitchy bugs like this and I find it difficult to want to play combined with the lag and framerate crawl. It needs a lot of work, to clean up the bugs and made it a smoother game. I wouldn't recommend it until those bugs are ironed out and the game runs smoothly. I give it a 3 out of 10.

content:
Posted: February 20, 2015
												Got it through Humble Bundle, so it was cheap as dirt, but even dirt can be too expensive at times.The game is horribly optimized, as it FPS-lagged like hell for me and the random people I was playing with. Moving the camera with the mouse was unbearably laggy and, without any better words to describe it, 'twitchy'. This would lead to deaths and getting stuck in spectator mode, which in turn bugged out only allowing watching the game from the death camera of another player.From what I understand it's basically an item-finding game, where you walk around a map looking for very small items that you can use to progress to the end of the level. Even without the monster to harrass you all the time, it's very hard, tedious and sadly also very boring. The premise wears out very quick, as it's basically just another Slender clone with new monsters and a multiplayer mode built on top.In the small amount of time I played the game I got it to crash 6 times, mostly when joining a server and getting stuck in the "Waiting for host to start the game" screen.I can't see anyone paying 20€ (or actually paying any sort of money) for this in its current state, so if you're interested, get it now while it's on Humble Bundle for the average price of the pack. Or, much rather, don't. It's not worth it.

My compter should be able to play this game fine (it's better than at least on of my friends computer and they can play).I've played alphas that work much better than this. Be warned that this is not (in my experience at least) a playble game.My friends seem to like the gameplay (something I have yet to experience) so maybe this will be good when the game is finished.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 8, 2016
												I really, really want to like this game and recommend it, but Damned has a range of bugs and glitches between a 7/15fps lock, monster glitches, other performance issues even on high-end PCs. The development of this game has been far too slow with updates not happening for months, and a promise to fix performance issues in 2014 but still hasn't been fixed as of 2016. The community has pretty much completely disappeared, so unless you're lucky and find an open server or have friends to play with you won't be getting very much game play out of this. I only decided to write this review because of how awful the performance bug is. I was originally running about 25fps, not good because my computer isn't great, but playable. Today I get on and I'm locked on 7fps. No updates since the last time I played was a week ago, Now in order to play with my friends I have to go through some annoying methods to try and unlock the fps. Uninstalling, restarting PC, reinstalling, adjusting settings both in an out of the game, I really enjoy the game when it runs well and when my friends play, but dealing with the bugs and stuff is incredibly annoying, and requires a ton of patience. Therefore, I cannot recommend this game to anyone for the price it is. If it ends up on sale and your friends have it, it may be worth the try. Maybe.Edit: After doing all the stuff to reset the framerate I now run 60fps, so my frames have been consistantly dropping.

												Survivarl. Horror. Co-op.Any one of those words would typically be enough to make me avoid a game.However, I was invited to play by some friends, and I'm glad I gave it a chance.This game is a LOT of fun.When playing with a group of friends, playing as either the monster or the survivors, either way it's a lot of fun.The diversity of the monsters keeps things interesting as well.Many levels keeps things feeling fresh.Some levels can feel fairly claustrophobic, and keys can be super hard to find. but I suppose that can add to the charm and experience of the game.At the end of the day, I played for several hours today, was freaking out over thinking I saw a monster when I ddin't, and getting killed constantly. content:
Posted: April 27, 2014
Early Access Review
								Really fun MULTIPLAYER horror game. There aren't that many multiplayer horror games, specially ones that are as fun as this.Think of it as Slenderman multiplayer combined with Amnesia the Dark descent.As a survivor you try to find keys to unlock different doors in the particular map, with the goal of eventually escaping. It's a group effort and when a player dies he/she drops the collected keys that someone has to grab again.As the monster you try to find and kill the survivors. There are several different monsters which all have they advantages and disadvantages. The monster is limited to what he can see, so it is pretty balanced in that sense.It is just fun to play this with friends and scare the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of them or be scared by a friend.

Play as the monster and scare the crap out of other gamers/your friends, or play as the survivor and be scared the crap out of as a Lurker spawns in front of you, a Phantom glides by you, or you start to hear the faint cries of Bloody Mary. It's simple but effective horror, and without all the disgusting gore and themes of Silent Hill or the like.TL;DR If you like BEING SCARED or SCARING OTHER PEOPLE, buy this game!

Posted: November 30, 2014
												This review is 9 months after my original one. To my surprise, little to nothing in this game is fixed, and in fact seems worse than before. 9 times out of 10, you can't just join a game. Instead, you'll crash and burn! Over and over again! The login system is still as useless as ever, and is just a waste of time. Useless DRM.Like I mentioned in my last review, unbalanced monster mechanics, locked to 30fps. Although, they recently fixed the frame-drops and general terribleness so that's a plus. Still not worth the $15 price tag. Get it on sale or don't get it at all and save yourself the frusturation of restarting the game constantly (and I mean constantly).This game being Early Access STILL does not let it get away with being near unplayable and broken. They've had almost a year to fix these issues, but instead of fix things they add more 'features' onto the game.Side-Note: Even if you don't crash, your friends sure can! Which means you have to restart the entire lobby just to play, and sometimes the entire game. It's better to just restart your game after every round.That's not to say this game doesn't have potential, it really does, but in its current form its awful. Steam really needs more quality control.EDIT: As of right now, apparently boards only go away for some people. So some people can't finish the game but others can walk through them. Good job!

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
Early Access Review
								Yes, I know it may not be the best looking game but honestly you guys...its so much fun. Its you and 4 of your friends (or strangers), one is the monster and 4 are the humans. humans run around finding keys to unlock doors to get to the safe zone. The monster has one goal, to kill all the player before they reach the safe zone. But the monster has 2 forms. Solid & Ghost. Solid for has a time limit, and ghost helps you move faster (but you cant see other players in ghost form)..."How do you know where the other players are at if you cant run around in solid for the whole time?" there are traps around each map that you can set and when the humans walk by them they set them off.This is really a game you have to get & play in order to like it. :)

content:
Posted: November 4, 2014
												Its an game that with some time and money is going to be one hell of a game,First of the idea of an Human controlled monster is absolutely epic, when in your every horror game ever, you know what the monster is and how it is coded, to what it reacts to, in here its different, you can know the mechanics of the monsters like one review suggested, but the human aspect of how the person plays the monster is different.I scared the crap out of my friends by playing very unpredictable, ie; they saw me and knew i would do some crazy♥♥♥♥♥♥ but i didnt, i just remembered the exact spot where they were and surprised them from a different direction, one of the post's suggested that you know what to do with each monster, this is the part where you come along, you can kill the survivers sometimes easily, but hey, whats the fun in that when you can do it so unpredictable causing jumpscares.Youre the monster, You decide what you do, and how you are going to do it.That was mostly for one of the earlier review's.All in all the game is not complete yet, with alot of FPS problems, Login problems, Connection problems, but i can forgive those, for this one will be a gem once it's edges have been smoothed.For now it has also problems with the maps being too similar, so there is not a large enough map creator implemented in the game, so it gets abit repeatitive, i wish they will add a bigger map generator system at some point, and would not hurt to have a few more monsters, 2/3 of the current ones im loving, 1 of them is not so much of a spooky one but more like ''i see it, i avoid it''..But as this is an indie game id give this an rating of 10/10 in indie'scompared to big studio games id give this one a 6/10if the changes and fixes i suggested will be implemented its gonna be atleast a 8/10

content:
Posted: July 18, 2016
												I wish I could play this one more, it's a blast with friends.You know what, I'll put it out there for anyone looking... It's not worth the price. It's a bit steep and this game is a bit buggy at times. It used to be so unbareable before, but that has been fixed. You know what, despite all the terrible problems my friends and I had, from not being able to connect to losing connection in about once every three or four games, we still played the damn game. Why? It's damn good, pun intended. There is many horror games out there with the enemies controllable. Typically, they stop feeling like horror games and more like competitive games. This one? It did a fantastic job keeping the game feel like a horror game. Though I myself only got scared only so few often (the only game that really consistently got me was Fatal Frame tbh), my friends would regularly scream in the headset. You have no idea how enjoyable and satisfying it is when you're the one causing that. So not only is it fun to be survivors, it's fun to be monsters. However, maybe not at first. The thing is, this game has a very steep learning curve, all from trial and erroring and random google search. The thing is, this game doesn't tell you a whole lot. You kinda just dive in and figure it out. Once you get over that hurdle, it's a ♥♥♥♥ing fantastic experience. The variety of monsters is great, all with different rules and gameplay mechanics that makes the game feel fresh for everyone. Some requires you to be sneaky, some requires you to be aggressive, some requires you to just be lucky. They're all fun to play for different reasons, some more than others.The human players have a simple goal of to simply progress. The levels change a bit, forcing players to look all over for keys and the likes. They have no way to fight the creatures for the most parts other than understanding some creatures require you to hide or else they can activate their attack by looking at you for too long. The human players really do feel like they're just trying to survive. The graphics, they're below mediocre. Goods news is that it's so dark, you'll rarely notice how bad they are. The atmosphere, the lighting, it all makes up for it all in my opinion. I'm not going to lie, I cannot stand some old 3D games, I am only human. I cannot even play PSOne games anymore because of my new set of standards. However, this game doesn't trigger any sore eyes. It is set up just fine. There is no single player, sadly, and online is pretty dead. Get this game on sale, get your friends on board, and have the time of your life. It has a four pack, use it. 8/10 (I give this score out a lot)Pros-Good gameplay, not too complexed and your goal is typically easy to figure outGreat atmosphere, feels like a true horror gameVariety of monsters, level resets that are always different, this isn't like L4D where it's always the same and you just speed run.Cons-It does feel pretty old sometimes. Definitely hope the developer makes a good sequel someday.Graphics are far from pretty, but you will not notice them too often with the lightingGame has its share of bugsLearning curve, it's obnoxious.The price, jesus christ... wait for a sale.

												Game doesn't tell you what you can do, how you can do it and the framerate is god-awful (locked at 15fps for some reason on a GeForce 660 and Quad core AMD).The game should lock down monster type to level, because some are blatantly overpowered for it.It doesn't tell you that you can open doors, and that you need to hold the left mouse button to drag and open the door.It doesn't tell you that you need to look at pumpkins to recharge, as a monster.The NAT traversal doesn't happen, and when a game is up and running, there can be an issue where your framerate drops to 1fps and freezes, unless the host quits.It's just buggy, I want to like it, the ghost mechanics kinda work but the people mechanics do not work, sprinting is a 'burst' type of thing and the controls are confusing and do not apply to every monster and it isn't clear what traits each monster has (place traps? teleport?).Needs serious repair and rebuild.

content:
Posted: October 31, 2014
												Damned, quite literally, is what you get when you take the concept of Evolve and make it pure Survival Horror. Everything is randomized, so no two games will be the same. The atmosphere of the game alone is enough to get your heart pounding (Assuming you have your gamma setting where it should be), and the Monsters available at the moment are scary. When I say Scary, I mean it. One Jump scares, another paces around 'blindly', and the other Stalks you with traps. Not only is this game scary, but it is a blast to play with friends (So much Trolling and purposeful scares without wanting to kill them yet). To think that this game is in Beta, it makes me anticipate what more they could add to such an already great game. Personally, I love it, and I recommend it to everyone. Just be warned when I say this is a great Horror game. If you do not like horror, don't get it. The biggest downside i see is that it is online only, but that is the premise of the game.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 5, 2015
												I start with the biggest problem with this game, and the reason of the "not recommended" stamp.It's the price. I can't believe how is that possible this game is 20€ without sale.  There are AAA games with lower price, and even indie games what are better made than this. You can't compare this game to them. The realistic price would be "free" , but keeping in mind this is a little indie developer team and needs money, I say 3-4€ at most. It doesn't worth more. Well, Steam keeps it at sale nowadays, but even on 66% it's a bit overpriced IMO, and the sale is just a bait.Now let's talk about the actual gameplay.Pros:-The concept is good.-The atmosphere is spooky (at least in the first few hours).-The three monsters are different, they are well made. -Some interesting map.-There's  big potential in this game, if the developers won't abandon it. -And the biggest pro of this game is that, it's very fun to play with friends...Cons:-... but without them it can be horrible, because it can easily lose the "fun factor". -As I said, after a few hours it is just not scary., you get used to it.-It's a bit unbalanced, if you don't learn fully how the monsters work. -Very, very unoptimized. I mean the graphics are bad, the maps are small, and the fps is horrible. Great combo.-As a survivor all you do is searching for keys, and opening doors. That's it. Of course you run from  the monster, and hide, but to progress you only need to search, search, search... -Opening doors, closets, drawers is ridicoulusly bad. You can fight 10-20 seconds with a simple door to open it.  Of course you can learn  to open them faster, but maybe it should be more important to make this usable, in a   game where half of the gameplay is opening doors... -There are a lot of bugs. I mean a bug can appear anywhere. Sometimes the server just freezes. Or the game runs with 1 FPS,   or you can't load the map.  Or the chat doesn't work. Or you can't login. Or you can't click on anything in the menu. Anything   that can happen,  in this game will hapen. (Murphy's law?)- The maps are repetitive. You can even mix up maps, because some part of them are just copy pasted from  an other map. They are not varied, they are boring.  Like there's a room full of  tables... then a room full of chairs... then a             room full of closets.. etc. (but as i said in the pros there are a few with good theme, and atmosphere)-The whole game feels amateurish. For 3-4€ I would say it's okay. But for 20€ it's just a giant NOPE. So when I suggest buying it?- If you like scary games, and you have friends to play with.- When it's on sale and it's price is just a  few € , or is in a pack with other games.

Posted: March 1, 2015
												This game's features actively work against itself.It's trying to be a horror game, but it's obtuse method of hiding the keys actively works to thwart any attempt at generating horror.  What it becomes is an exercise in Schadenfreude as one friend gleefully kills the rest while no progress is made.  The "Haunts" are nothing more than tedious time-wasters that give an advantage to the already advantaged monster player. End of the day, this is a horror game that fails to scare, and barely manages to be a game.  Do not buy.

												Dont buy this game until the devs fix these massive netcode issues.So this game WAS great, and now its unstable.It was a great idea, and still is.It used to be relatively stable, and now is toally error prone.It was a great time with friends and randoms, but now is frustratingAnd then the Menu-Game came. content:
Posted: December 20, 2014
												Fun with friends but the amount of bugs and glitches makes this a horrible mess of a game that only shines in a few moments.The premise is easy, you are dropped in a small map and you are either a "survivor" or a "monster" with the choice between three different monsters each with their own powers and personalities. However before this can be done you have to register??? for python some reason even though this game plays through steam. Sometimes this results in a crash and makes your game freeze and you have to use taskmanager to close it. restart... Now you probably want to fiddle with the graphical options as the game look and runs terrible. turning down the visual options helps getting the FPS from 8 to 25 easily...this game looks like it was made in unity like all the easy-to-make-horror-games of the last few years. However changing the graphical options makes the game hate you and freezes again, open task manager and close the game again. Now we get to join a room and this is where the fun begins. Because it's ALWAYS a gamble if you wil connect correctly. Sometimes the game joins a room but places you in a kind of limbo that shows no other players and doesn't allow you to start a game in any way, shape or form. the other kind is where it freezes upon start, open task manager bla bla bla...This game has a good concept and is really fun when it works however before you even get it to work you're already half an hour further and that is just not acceptable nowaday. If you want a good time with friends buy it on sale as a four-pack to have some laughs if you have the patience to get it all working.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2016
												Is your PC too slow to run Dead By Daylight?Well you've come to the right place.This game involves 4 survivors pinned up against one of the four monsters:-Mary (Teleports and goes on a "frenzy" that allows her to kill those close to her)-Phantom (Can't see you unless you're running or close to it)-Lurker (Is invisible to survivors, and traps are invisible to him, his attacks are based on sounds made by traps)-Fallen (Becomes visible once 10 traps are set and will destroy everything)To win as the survivors you must collect keys to open doors in order to look for the items required to escape.  In order to escape you must find both a silver key and a crowbar/hammer.  Once you find these items you can break open the exit door and have everyone escapeThe Game is very balanced in my opinion, a very good monster can kill all survivors, and a well organized team can escape with some effort.The game isn't completely dead, but I do reccomend having at least one friend buy it as well as it can make for much more fun experiences, and the game is pretty low on players.TLDR: It's an older version of Dead By Daylight with different mechanics and lower graphics.  It's a great game, and I'd easily give it a 9/10.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												2/10good concept but the negatives weigh out the positives by a ton.positives are that it is a good concept, good idea, and the monster ideas are a good touch.The negatives far outweigh those though.----Let's start with the fact that I could not even sign in.  Every single time I boot the game up I have to restart the entire game (exit the game completely) at least 3-4 times.  Half the time when i go to log it, it says that I can't log in because my account is in use by someone else.  Eventually I could log in, but the problems don't end there.I tried joining his game, but half the time just joining his game it was broken to where I joined his lobby, but neither of us were actually there and we couldn't start it.  That requires me restarting 3 or 4 times.-I first tried playing as the phantom with my friend on a one on one match.  Eventually after floating around for half an hour I asked him if he could see where I was, because the survivors should be able to see the phantom, but not the other way around.  I lined his sight up so he would be able to see me, but in his game I was not present. (I would know, I'm sitting right next to him) -From what I could tell the lurker seemed to be fine from my experience.-Mary, oh mary, where do I even start?--I played Mary and I literally could not play her.--The first game I played i was trapped in a room, so I teleported out, normal right?  Well then I tried to teleport out again and it never let me teleport again that game.  I was literally stuck in that small room with no escape.--Eventually we started up a new game and I did the same thing, except I teleported into a larger room the second game.  I was walking around for half an hour while my friend walked around the map figuring it out.  Eventaully he said he just got scared because he saw me...except I never left the main room I was stuck in..  I looked over at his screen and my character was moonwalking in his room and then randomly teleported out.  So I asked him if he could walk into the room where i was stuck.  Apparently that room that I was stuck in was one he had also been walking around for 20 minutes as well.  He literally could not see me, and i could not see him (I'm still playing as mary at this point), and all the doors that were open for him, were still closed for me, which is why I never knew he was there. --We booted it back up (after me restarting three or four times) and i tried Mary one more time.  Except this time I did nothing.  I did not move from the starting location from where I spawned in on the map as Mary.  I then went to his screen and watched him, hoping to help him find my room to simply see if I was there.  But not only did he not find me, a random mary once again was in his game and teleported right in front of him and was moonwalking.  Obviously this both freaked us out!  Except...I'm supposed to be Mary walking around....and my Mary never moved from her starting spot.  At that point I just turned the game off. (yes all of these games I am in his game/player list currently playing)All in all this game is not worth the time most likely unless it is fixed in a major way.  This game is in now way worth 20 dollars especially in this state.  I'm dissapointed that I paid for this, as it was not a wise purchase from what I could tell.  Buy this at your own risk, as it is broken beyond all belief atm.  If anyone has any help to give me, I'd love to hear it, as I would love for this game to work, but as of now, it's impossible for me to play.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2014
												TL;DR: So bad, not worth.Aside from the constant crashing at the start and insane lag even when running on a computer well beyond this game's requirements, there is pretty much no content. You spend ages in an almost atmospherically devoid environment looking for keys and various other crap without a clear objective aside from 'escape (insert random room here).'Then comes the random♥♥♥♥♥ambience. You hear random things like what sounds like a hotel clerk bell and little bits of laughter for no reason.With these immersion-disrupting sound bits tearing through your skull and the random screen darknening which is also jarring, you are very aware that you are playing a game. There is no mistaking it, the immersion leaves a lot to be desired. Also, the enemies aren't particularly scary. If you see an enemy, you die silently. I tend to just run straight into the enemies because I feel 0 fear at all after the ambience has disrupted everything. The enemies are creepy-ish in their models alone because they arent particularly well done and it leaves a dirty-ish gross effect. Aside from that the game has pretty much nothing going for it.Cool concept, poorly executed design, no immersion, not worth the 5 dollar sale.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2014
												Is this game still in alpha? Don't get me wrong, Damned is an amazing game; the 10% of the time you can actually play it. But in it's current state it's simply unplayable.- The game crashes much more often than it doesn't. When you start a match it's VERY common for at least 2-3 of the 5 players to drop out because their game crashed. Judging by the fact the game is using 1,000,000k+ memory when I kill it, there's a memory leak somewhere. - Upon rebooting the game, there's a myriad of random glitches. The most notable is the broken login screen. Others include sound simply not working, and lobbies not forwarding you into matches. Outside of these glitches, there's a missing element to this game that's required for horror. There's almost no sound effects. Lurker lurches up to you and ravages you with his giant claws? COMPLETELY SILENT. There's spookity music playing, but you die without a sound. This is a huge problem with Mary, a little girl monster. If she stands near a survivor long enough she goes into a frenzy, and can completely wipe the whole party in seconds. You'd expect for there to be some sort of audio cue when she's nearby, you know to scare you, but nope. There's supposed to be a sobbing noise, but it's so faint(even with that audio maxed) that you can't realistically hear it. The last problem I have with this game is that fact that monsters can cheese really hard if they know the map. Last night I witnessed a match where there was 1 survivor left, who had all the items he needed to escape out the final door. The enemy monster, the Phantom, was simply floating in front of the escape, slashing the air in front of the door. There was nothing the survivor could do. He had to open that door to win, and if he tried he would get killed. The game has great potential, but until they fix their codebase you'll be fighting with the game's menus and glitches a lot more than playing the game.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2014
 Well to put it simply the game is good, but it's not quite Carling. I have given the game a positive review because in it's current state i would say that it is quite playable for all there are a few bugs with the game give or take.For instance there are a few irritating ones with the menu's and the lobbies. The player will get a message 'The servers are down/disconnected' Or the player might get stuck in a lobby, unable to join a game or accept invites.In-game there are not that many bugs i have encountered myself, although there is the odd random floating pumpkin here and odd floating non interactable keys there [Since the games objective is to gather keys this may or may not have an affect on the experience]. The game is currently quite stable.The game is labeled as a 'Horror'. And it isn't that bad of a one. I can compare the game slightly to that of Slender Man, only it being 5 player online and you don't collect pages you collect keys. With three monsters to choose from and an interacial gang of meddling kids that need to escape from a spooky house or forest before Jim can 'Fix-em'. The game is quite promising.Although the game doesn't quite have that real 'I just♥♥♥♥♥♥my pants' feel, it will give you quite a few jumps scares and a mild heart attack every now and then. [Well... Unless it's Mary, then you will probably need to go and change.]So all in all it is quite a good Horror. And looks like it could develop into something quite good. If i could rate this Half & Half i would, but i'm going to stick with the positive for now.

number of helpful: 7 of 12 people (58%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 19, 2014
												A friend bought me this game and I still feel ripped off, god forbid you pay the full $19.99 for this game.In short, this game is incredibly shallow and is obviously just a cash grab to get money from youtube lets players.In long:The gameplay doesnt even need to be boiled down to explain it, all you do is wander around a map trying its hardest to be scary (which is ruined immediately by the jack-o-lanterns) and pick up items, then you use these items to progress in the map and ultimately try to escape, the monster's job is to simply kill all the players.This sounds great, except the entirety of the gameplay hinges around a single player, the monster. If the monster is playing to win, then the monster will win. EVERY. TIME. The monster has to 'play along' and try to actually scare the players, otherwise people will just drop dead and not understand why, as nothing is particularly clear and monsters will instantly kill you often before you even see them.The maps have confusing layouts with no real logic tying them together with items strewn about in a random fashion, there are so many locked doors and rusty keys that it gets confusing very quickly.The monster design is pretty horrible as well.Mary just waits on a charge bar (that charges faster if the survivors look at you) then goes into frenzy and can instantly kill a player in a dash.The Phantom can't see players unless they make sounds, except literally everything bar standing still makes sound, so basically it becomes a game of 'stand still and stare at the monster to survive', which can be easily abused and makes for a pretty idiotic mechanicThe Lurker is probably the only decently designed monster, as they place 'sound traps' where if a survivor trips it, both the survivor and the lurker knows it, the lurker then spawns in the area and looks for the survivor. However the lurker is on a 15 second timer giving survivors a chance to actually survive.Finally, the game is buggy and fairly unfinished, with crashes around every corner, mysterious performance drops with no relation to hardware, horrible netcode, and connection issues.Basically? DON'T BUY THIS GAME, IT ISNT EVEN WORTH 20 CENTS LET ALONE 20 DOLLARS.

content:
Posted: January 31, 2014
Early Access Review
								The general idea and concept behind this game is great, Basically the game is similar to amnesia but with friends, and as we all know anything with friends is better even if the gameplay is dreaded.In this case the gameplay is actually pretty good, Jump scares tend to be common and if u really jack the music up hairs will rase.Playing as the monster is difficult but easy to pick up once you get going and alot of laughs can be had, playing as a human on the other hand can be scary to say the least, with a first person camera style and rather hard to see without your flash light on making this game one of those games where the more friends you have working together generally makes you wonder if its better to split up or stay together.The main part that lets this game down significantly (at the moment atleast) is the fact that the game crashes constantly when entering or leaving a match, making actually getting into the game rather frustating to say the least not only that but the game isnt too well optimised at the momnet and even with everything turned down the game can at times run pretty badly.If you have a group of friends this game is worth looking at if your up for a night of scares and fun, otherwise for now you can give it a missOverall Damned is a fun but scary game but in its current ALPHA state this game could be given a miss for a while id only recommend this game if you have friends willing to play with you.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												I had a blast playing this game for the first time last night.  Was playing with several friends, and we were taking turns playing the monster.  I had a ton of fun tormenting my friends as Mary, a monster that is basically the little girl from The Ring.  I would see their flashlights shining around, and I would just try to stand somewhere just out of sight, so they'd turn the corner and see me standing there motionless, and then yell and run.  Once, a new friend joined the game, and he saw me standing still, and wasn't sure if I was the monster or what.  He just kept his light on me and was asking in voicechat if the girl was a monster or a friendly.  Then I suddenly went into frenzy mode and rushed directly at him.  The resulting shrieks of terror had me laughing my♥♥♥♥♥off.  The game was a lot of fun, and we'll definitely be playing some more.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 20, 2014
Early Access Review
								A rather interesting concept that we don't often see. Works well with 5 friends, not so much with random people. Unless said random people all leave their mics open or join a teamspeak server and share in good laughs when they get freaked out by a monster appearing in front of them or tearing them to pieces.Ultimately though, this game is lacking variety right now. It is an Alpha, so I will give it that. The gameplay is simple, find the keys or codes to unlock doors or safes to find more keys and codes. Eventually, you'll find a tool to pull wooden boards off of a door. After that door is unlocked you escape from the monster. There are a few maps so far, so it does get repetitive eventually. Withut any dynamic events happening, I don't think it will ever stop being repetitive. Anyways, there are only two monsters aka creatures. One of which is not as fun as the other.There's the Phantom. Which is the not-so-fun monster. As the Phantom you float around as a half decayed torso imbued with some evil magic or something. You float around decently fast and are allowed to pass through closed doors. Which is the only thing scary about this monster. From only a few play attempts it was clear to me that it was pretty overpowered and did not provide that great of an experience, both for the monster player, nor the character players.The second and so far final monster, the Lurker is a rather intimidating piece of work. Though when I think about it, I find that it also resembles the Phantom in a way as they share a common trait. They both can get through closed doors. The Lurker is a little more difficult to get through though. There are two phases to this monster. Your "ghost" phase, and your "flesh" phase. In the ghost phase you are unable to see or hear the players, but you're allowed to set traps. The traps range from pianos, to kitchen timers, to creaky boards. Unfortunately there are no visual traps like falling chairs, chandeliers, or candles that would blow out or anything like that. Then if you are near a trap you set that goes off, you click and change into your flesh form for a limited time. In this time you are to chase down and kill the player near you.For the Alpha that it is. Damned is definitely entertaining. If you are a streamer, this is a good kind of game to play with friends while live. Especially if you're easily scared/really jumpy. But don't play it too much or you'll get bored!For the Alpha that it is, I give it a 6.5/10.It definitely needs some updates to add some more fun to it. More creatures, more maps, and hopefully eventually some more dynamism. - Codewow

content:
Posted: July 17, 2015
												This game is a great one, though I wish there was more content. The games are randomized on different maps, and the point is to basically find keys to unlock doors so you can escape. The keys aren't in the same places, however, so the game is challenging every time. You play with 3 other "survivors", pitted against the player-controlled monster. Each one is drastically different from each other, giving you a different experience for each one. Lurker is invisible and blind to players, until one of them sets off one of his traps. The Phantom is blind to players, except for when they are making noises, or are directly(like, two feet) in front of him. Mary is scary. Also deadly. She's your worst nightmare. One moment she's there, the next she's gone. Then you die.As I write this review, there's been no updates since April. The game is still great, fully playable. I'f you've ever wanted to play Amnesia with friends, then this game is probably for you. Highly reccomended

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 3, 2014
												Let me start off by saying that I really love this game, or rather the potential this game has. In its current state I feel it falls short of what it could be.  I first bought this game roughly a year ago, and I'm disappointed with the amount of work that has gone into it since then.  This game doesn't need *more* content, it needs *refinement* of the existing content. I sincerely hope the developers will consider making some of the following adjustments:Criticisms:1) Communication.  Typically, most players choose to have their character randomly assigned.  The unfortunate side effect is that you don't know who YOU are playing as (assuming you're a human). Trying to tell your fellow survivors where items are becomes very difficult when they cant match your voice to your character.  Simply adding a portrait of your character on screen somewhere would help greatly.2) Prolonged stalemates.  Most of the games I have played follow the same pattern, monster gets an early kill, eventually kills off a couple more, and then 3 players are stuck watching a stale mate of 1 monster vs 1 human for 20 minutes.  To exacerbate the problem, the dead players can't communicate with the living, which leaves both parties wondering if they should just give up for the sake of starting a new game.   I feel like some kind of mechanic needs to be implemented to bring the game to an end when it gets stalled in this way.  At the very least, players need to communicate how long they are willing to wait before abandoning the game.3) Limited flash light usage.  When I first read about this in patch notes, it sounded exciting and a way to make the game more suspenseful.  In reality, it seems to bring the game to a grinding halt for all parties.  As a human, when your battery dies you cease making progress, and end up walking in circles aimlessly.  As the monster, your prey becomes harder to find, and the game reaches another stalemate.4) Anti-climactic endings.  Regardless of which side wins, the game often ends with a yawn.  If a monster sneaks up and kills you from behind, you just fall over dead with out much idea of what happened to you.  If the survivors win, you just abruptly get notified that the game is over and are sent back to the lobby.  It would be nice if player deaths had a little more animation or violence added (it is a horror game after all), or if the survivors attempting to open the last door triggered some kind of global warning that would give the monster a brief moment of opportunity to get to the exit and stop them.I really hope the developers will address these issues, as I've been a huge advocate of this game to many of my friends and coworkers.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2014
												Played with a full group of friends. Everyone, including the monster - on Skype. We figured we can't really tell each other where we were because of that, so I came up with the brilliant idea of using turning on and off my flashlight to indicate to the others. We proceed to find a bunch of keys and stuff - so far so good.5 minutes later one of my buddies is dead and another one has splitted off the group so it's just the two of us searching the level. Shortly we find the key to the exit, my heart is racing, all excited and stuff when the one who went to search alone starts shouting on Skype that the monster is chasing him. The keys aren't in the same places, however, so the game is challenging every time. You play with 3 other "survivors", pitted against the player-controlled monster. The Phantom is blind to players, except for when they are making noises, or are directly(like, two feet) in front of him. Mary is scary. Also deadly. She's your worst nightmare. Early Access Review
								Very suspenseful and exciting. When played at night with friends, Damned is incredibly entertaining. The immersion is accentuated by 3D directional voice communication, which is honestly one of my favorite features for a game to have.Visually, the game isn't ridiculously impressive; although, its graphics and effects do fine at achieving the game's spooky atmosphere.My only qualm is with the volumetric fog. Hopefully the developers find some way to better optimize the fog for performance.Overall: Great game, very spooky 8.5/10

												Very spooky and fun to play with your friends.But there's a lot of bugs, the game sometimes crashes after the loading screen without a message, and in some places you can't for example walk between two tables, even though there is plenty of space. You may also not be able ot walk over the slighest obstacle, an Ouija board for example. Theres also no level editor, which makes me sad.Doors, drawers and lockers can be very difficult to open, as the game has a very severe case of mouse acceleration, along with a bit clunky controls.It can be EXTREMELY hard for the survivors to complete a match, since some of the maps are very VERY linear, and with keys being difficult to find at most time. The phantom monster is very OP, since you only have to camp at a door in one the linear maps to win the entire game in just a few seconds. I highly suggest you play with life mode and set max deaths to 6.The game has a real neat 3D voice feature, which means the host can change it so that you can only hear people speak if they were close to you. This can be frustrating though if you're playing a large map with many ways to go.Totally not worth 20 euro in it's current state, but if its on sale and you get it for 3,99 as I did, you should totally get it.I rate this game 6/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 3, 2014
												Let me start off by saying that I really love this game, or rather the potential this game has. In its current state I feel it falls short of what it could be.  I first bought this game roughly a year ago, and I'm disappointed with the amount of work that has gone into it since then.  This game doesn't need *more* content, it needs *refinement* of the existing content. I sincerely hope the developers will consider making some of the following adjustments:Criticisms:1) Communication.  Typically, most players choose to have their character randomly assigned.  The unfortunate side effect is that you don't know who YOU are playing as (assuming you're a human). Trying to tell your fellow survivors where items are becomes very difficult when they cant match your voice to your character.  Simply adding a portrait of your character on screen somewhere would help greatly.2) Prolonged stalemates.  Most of the games I have played follow the same pattern, monster gets an early kill, eventually kills off a couple more, and then 3 players are stuck watching a stale mate of 1 monster vs 1 human for 20 minutes.  To exacerbate the problem, the dead players can't communicate with the living, which leaves both parties wondering if they should just give up for the sake of starting a new game.   I feel like some kind of mechanic needs to be implemented to bring the game to an end when it gets stalled in this way.  At the very least, players need to communicate how long they are willing to wait before abandoning the game.3) Limited flash light usage.  When I first read about this in patch notes, it sounded exciting and a way to make the game more suspenseful.  In reality, it seems to bring the game to a grinding halt for all parties.  As a human, when your battery dies you cease making progress, and end up walking in circles aimlessly.  As the monster, your prey becomes harder to find, and the game reaches another stalemate.4) Anti-climactic endings.  Regardless of which side wins, the game often ends with a yawn.  If a monster sneaks up and kills you from behind, you just fall over dead with out much idea of what happened to you.  If the survivors win, you just abruptly get notified that the game is over and are sent back to the lobby.  It would be nice if player deaths had a little more animation or violence added (it is a horror game after all), or if the survivors attempting to open the last door triggered some kind of global warning that would give the monster a brief moment of opportunity to get to the exit and stop them.I really hope the developers will address these issues, as I've been a huge advocate of this game to many of my friends and coworkers.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 10, 2015
												The good:-Freaking scary. Really.And it gets a lot scarier once your mates die. The fact that the monster isn't some dumb AI that you can habitually outplay makes it more scary than anything. You truly do not know what to expect.-Very fun with friends using Skype, TS or something similar. More on that later.-Very-very interesting, unique gameplay. This is the biggest point for me.The bad:-Sometimes too scary. This wouldn't be a point if there weren't some group pressure on you to open that door behind which there MAY be a monster. In single player, you save or simply go out for a drink if you had too much. Here, there is no getting away from the fact that you HAVE to keep going, even when you feel like you just can't take it anymore-Much-much worse without voice communication. Apart from the practicality of not being able to scream : "OH♥♥♥♥♥♥ TURN AROUND AND RUN!!!" You can easily get lost and separated from your buddies, and not being able to communicate fluently makes the game irritating instead of terrifying. Lack of communication really hurts your experience, and not having people to play with can be bad, because random people won't talk to you.-You're kinda not supposed to actually win as a survivor. The point is the promise of survival which you can actually google or find on youtube: is possible. But there is an invincible monster that 1shots you between you and victory and this turns the odds heavily in the monsters favour. So although you CAN win, I wouldn't count on it happening more often than 1 in a dozen games or so (I still haven't won). So while you are actually terrified, the one who gets the most 'fun' out of it is the monster.-Bugs, crashes everywhere. I have issues starting the game about every 3rd match.-THE DOORS!!! HOW HARD CAN IT BE to code them properly? They are a real struggle to operate. I wish they just abandoned the idea of making them drag-or-push based and instead just click on them to open, at least I could open and close them whenever I want to with security.-Some levels are just crap. Some of them are very-very simple where you progress from room to room, say, you need to find key 1 in room 1 so you can get to room 2, where you need to find key 2 to room 3....the problem with this is that the monster knows EXACTLY where you will be, and apart from juking him around the tables there is very little you can do. (As the monster: They will be in room 2. Just go there and kill them)-Mary is just unfair. You can play around the other two, and if you get killed you can find an error in your gameplay. With Mary, you die because she ported next to you. GG.That's about all I could think of. And while I listed more bad points than good points, the good ones still weight more heavily than the bad ones.Get this game if:-It's on sale-If you have friends to play with-If you are a hardcore horror fan and can stand the pressure-If you are a lucky ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and count on being the monster more often than not-If you have the nerves to grind out the neccessary game experience to win despite paralyzing terror.-If your name is Mary.Overall: great game, but not without buddies, and not so much if you are a ♥♥♥♥♥ like me. :(

												If you're interested in Damned, then you have to be ready to put up with a handful of things including, but not limited to, that one missing key, the fact that the game doesn't always 100% work for everyone consistently due to bugs or other nonsense, and last, but not least, the fact that mary is scary. This game is an exciting horror escape game that feels kind of like a point and click game given a first person engine, only because you're running around to specific rooms and running through them to grab at keys to open new rooms etc. Knowledge is probably the most valuable weapon in this game because an inexperienced player is almost always going to lose, but that's all part of the horror fun as the monster gets to toy with them a little bit beforehand. All in all the game has its unique charm, but you will most likely have to have a group of 5 friends to really enjoy the game to its fullest.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 7, 2015
												Worth it on a Steam sale when all your friends buy it and play together. HOWEVER I have a very important issue with this game that other people have as well. The Insanity System is literally one of the most annoying and disappointing things I have ever seen for a game. I hate horror games, movies etc, but I love it when the scares derive from the PLAYERS in the game, like in this one! But just less than an hour ago the Insanity System has caused me to stop playing due to fear. I didn't even know this feature was in the game until earlier when I was hiding from a friend playing as Mary (who is TERRIFYING) and a CREEPY AS♥♥♥♥♥♥FACE FLASHED ONTO MY SCREEN and I think I pooped myself. Yes I get scared a bit easily but again, this had the potential to make me enjoy a horror game which I usually don't like as a genre. I play Depth, a game with sharks and the ocean, when I am terrified of BOTH, and I love it, because the scares are natural, balanced and fair.The Insanity System saps all fun from the experience as the scares are no longer being produced from a balanced, real system. When someone is playing as the monster and you get scared, it's OK because you know they were simply using the game's features, which you understand and have the ability to counteract based on your knowledge of the monster.Now it's not ALL bad. Some of the features include strange noises/music playing, the lights flickering, and even your keyboard keys losing response. Despite the keys thingy, I think those ideas are alright as long as they create TENSION and not FEAR. The one feature of the Insanity System that RUINS the experience are the face jumpscares (I think it's the people who have died flash onto your screen?) that occur when you have been alive and hiding for a while.When a face flashes onto your screen, you have absolutely NO idea when, where or why it appears and it's not even controlled by the player as the monster. It's an unfair system that ruins the balance. The monster and humans have an equal environment to win. A face flashing onto your screen is random and unfair.Overall a very fun game but the Insanity System is making me fear playing it again in case it shows up again. If there was an option to remove it, I would love this a lot more. Would love if the faces got removed or turned into an option, considering how the devs have been aware of the dislike for this feature for about seven to eight months.

content:
Posted: March 20, 2015
												15 hours in with friends, I must say that I heavily enjoyed Damned. This is coming from someone that normally hates first-person unarmed horror games on PC. The concept of the game is honestly brilliant. Each monster has mechanics that are unique to them and make all of them interesting to play as (although I think Phantom needs a bit more buffing in order to be more balanced).As for survivors, it's interesting how the way the game works encourages people to work together BUT not stay close. That could mean immediate disaster, especially against the likes of Lurker or Mary. The sanity meter is also very neat and adds to the intensity. I also like how the doors work in this game. Makes it MUCH more challenging to escape from nasty situations.The only thing I think needs a LOT of work is sound design. The game itself can build tension in many situations and is scary in certain ways, but sound design is very choppy and some of the sound effects they chose are incredibly cliche and immediately take me out of the game (randomly heard an Evil Witch laugh that I swear I heard on one of those Halloween spooky sounds CDs you can get at convenience stores). Mary's music is also very cheap-sounding and generic. I'd honestly turn the music volume to 0 if it weren't for the rest of the soundtrack being solid.The game also still needs polishing. I've ran into glitches where we were unable to actually complete the stage, people would be stuck in the lobby despite the host starting the match, and Mary has been able to siphon energy off dead bodies and regain frenzy almost immediately after using it. I understand this game has recently stopped being Early Access? I still think they need to fix a lot of things before deciding that. Still, I'm sure they're working on it! Just 7 folks with a great concept, after all.This is honestly one of the best horror games I've played in a long time. It really makes me glad someone can use this 'helpless defenseless first-person horror' genre to make something actually very enjoyable.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 19, 2014
												Ohh my God, this game is absolutely flipping amazing.  Buy this game if you have friends who play it (or are willing to play),  as this would probably be a lonely experience single-player.  In the Lobby, you can choose to be either a Monster or its potential Victim.  Right now there are only three Monsters to choose from, so I hope that will change.  Of the Monsters available I've played as Mary and the Lurker.  Mary is your typical ghost girl, slow-moving, but get close to potential Victims and you can enter a Frenzy mode in which to attack.  As the Lurker, you can activate objects within the level that will set off traps/cues if your potential victims walk near or activate the items themselves.  Victims are invisible while you are in "normal mode," but you can manifest physically and hunt your victims down.A lot of the fun of this game will likely come from playing with friends and using the voice-chat.  The buddies I game with all use TeamSpeak, and whenever I played as Monster I either groaned or spoke in a sing-song voice, and my friends were screaming like young girls.One thing I don't understand is whether a potential Victim can actually survive.  There seems to be no way for potential Victims to defend themselves against Monsters, so it's down to hunting for the right keys as quickly as possible.  It also seems that, once a Monster closes in, it's a one-click attack and you go from potential Victim to actual Victim.I would request that a third-person mode be made available, because what's the point of being a Monster when you can't enjoy the look?In all, I really got into the role of Monster and actually felt a little anxious as I ran around as a potential Victim when it was my friends' turns to hunt.  This has all the qualities of a good "scary story by the campfire."  It may not be a "true" horror game like the Silent Hill franchise, but it's still a pretty damn neat idea.
