number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 16, 2014
Early Access Review
								BRIEF SYNOPSIS: You can have great jump scares with this beta 3D multiplayer horror adventure where you play either one of four survivors trying to escape, or a horrifying monster attempting to kill the survivors; recommended despite bugs (see forums). * Spoilers below *GAMEPLAY REVIEW:Summary:My childhood nightmares come to life. I'm a wimp when it comes to anything horror, but the multiplayer adventurer in me as drawn me in. It is brilliant to have four different human survivors as a team versus one human-controlled monster. And the three current monsters are terrifying, along with the ten existing levels full of creepy ambiance and atmosphere.Escape is difficult but not impossible for the survivors, who need to find keys and codes to unlock and open doors and safes, use batteries to power their flashlights, grab a crowbar or hammer to smash wooden boards, and eventually escape the monster or fall victim to it. The longer it takes to complete a level, the more the survivors become insane and the more difficult it becomes to escape.In game chat:I really enjoyed using the 3d audio with a microphone headset. It makes a huge difference in the game. Everyone can hear you speaking, so if you want to keep the monster guessing use the in-game text chat (brought up with the enter key). It's also good with chatting in-between rounds in the lobby.Game play seems to favour the monsters, but smart survivors will be able to team up to outwit their pursuer to escape. Even in death, survivors can text chat with the living to give helpful hints, such as “You missed a key in the sink,” or “I have a crowbar with my body on the main floor.”Lobby:After logging in you can setup your options and either join or host your own game. Hosts can have an open game lobby or set a password to have a private game amongst friends only. Some people have complained about being kicked out of games but I think most people who want private games have figured out how to the use password now. Those of you still kicking people, stop being so lazy and use a password for your private games (May the Lurker devour your soul...). The people hosting and the people I've played with in this community have been courteous and fun to play with. Thanks people for making this game even more fun! Most people seem to be on the servers during the weekends.Life mode seems better if you are casually hosting players – people can join in whenever they feel like if there is a spot. Normal mode is more hard core with only one life to live or die with.Levels:There are currently ten levels consisting of three hotels, three asylums, a hospital (asylum set), a restaurant (hotel set), a warehouse (hotel set), and a factory. Each are different sizes and have different strategies. Some have two exits which help prevent monster camping at the exit. Some have stairs and different levels. Some have too many damn tables. Each level is creepy and atmospheric. I AM HOPING FOR GRAVEYARD TYPE LEVELS FOR A FUTURE UPDATE. There are only three different set types for levels (asylum, hotel, or factory).Survivors:There are four player controlled survivor models:Mia the emo; she appears to be Asian and wears miss-matching shoes.Scott the jockey, sporting his Eagles college jacket.Jacob the nerd; he is of African descent and a little stout.Father John the priest; he totes a Bible but it's not compelling monsters to go away.The survivors typically start in a room and have to find keys and codes to unlock doors and safes that will eventually allow them to escape from the level. The survivors are equipped with a battery burning flashlight that needs to be replenished or they will be forced to grope around in the dark. The longer the survivors take to complete a level, the more insane they will become. Others tools survivors will need include either a crowbar or a small hammer to remove boards from exit or storage doors. [A shovel is needed in the graveyard level.] - oops, sorry, don't know how that got in there... There are no weapons or way to attack the monster, which makes then all the more scary. Repeat, there is no BFG to save you!Monsters:There are currently three monsters that one player can choose to hunt down the survivors. I feel the monsters are generally well-balanced. Some people feel the Phantom is still overpowered, despite all the tweaks it has been receiving as of late. Survivors must adjust their game-play for each monster in order to escape.Mary is the scariest monster and my current favourite. She is a great monster with pretty blue eyes, but she has some posture issues. She seems well balanced with her movements and attacks. Her walk mode is a little slow, but her attack is long reaching and swift. Quick manoeuvring for survivors is the key when you hear her scream. Mary has some movement issues over objects and the Factory catwalk.The Lurker is a muscular hulk with two forms. The first form is spiritual and allows the Lurker to freely roam the level, unencumbered by doors. In this mode it can set sound traps that go off when a survivor is nearby to help it locate the players as it cannot see anyone in this form. Once the Lurker is powered up by time it can enter its physical form where it can visibly stalk and kill remaining survivors. After a while the Lurker will revert to its spiritual form where it will have to wait until it recharges and takes physical form again. The longer the Lurker remains in physical form, the longer it take to recharge in spiritual form.The Phantom is a roaming skeletal ghost (the creepiest monster for me until Mary joined) that can see survivors via sound such as the clicking of flashlights, running, or setting off a trap. Then it's either run away for the survivors and try to escape the Phantoms detection radius or get eviscerated by it. When the Phantom hears a survivor, it can see a white shadow, even through walls or different levels, of where the player is.Traps are set automatically for the Phantom and Mary, whereas setting traps is part of the Lurker's strategy. They are generally objects strewn about the level. Each trap makes a different sound to alert a monster to where a survivor is.Sound:The music is great for a horror game. Each monster has its own terrifying theme music when it appears near a survivor. Ambient sounds like footsteps, breathing, traps, and screams add to the atmosphere. The 3D audio chat really adds to the game-play; it is great to taunt the survivors as a monster. Dead players can only text chat.Insanity system:The insanity system increases game difficulty by darkening a survivor's screen to the point of complete darkness, making the flashlight flicker on and off, causing the player to hear random sounds, losing hearing, losing colour vision, having arms emerge from the ground that slow or halt a survivor's progress, randomly disabling a directional key on your keyboard, and flashing images of possessed survivors across your screen. The effects are temporary but potentially deadly.The insanity mode is a great idea and has been toned down from beta 1.0 to occur less frequently. It serves its purpose of making the game especially difficult the longer the survivors take to exit. Apparently the jump scare faces have been fixed so that they don't blind you, but I have yet to see the new effect since my game currently freezes before it occurs. I feel the jump scares are not necessary in this game. Also annoying for fair game-play is the keyboard/mouse movement disabling effect.CONCLUSION:Despite bugs being ironed out during the beta period, I feel the game is a very enjoyable if not a mildly terrifying experience. It's best played with all five people, and the up to four survivors really need to cooperate to escape from the monster. Recommended for beta and if all bugs (especially game freezing/crashing) get squashed for the retail release.Edited 2014-08-26 - [Version Beta 1.12a]

content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
Early Access Review
								While I find this game really fun, especially in the first time in the areas, I was so unfamiliar and getting horribly frightened especially when the lurker set off item traps so everything started dinging and going off around me.As fun as it is, I feel the level variety and maps could be a bit more mazelike, confusing to both the monster and the humans, making it harder to track as well as potential changes to monster styles. As stated in another players review, they recommended a way of allowing the Lurker to interact directly with objects to scare people, without actually being able to kill them. Beyond that, I find the Lurker insanely fun with setting traps and waiting for the careless humans to set off my traps to alert me to their location. I remember once I waited for the traps to alert me, and as soon as one right next to me went off, I turned physical, staring face to face mere feet away from 2 humans, who both panicked in their attempts to run away.In addition, I feel that the Phantom should have its range reduced a bit and if possible, sound waves emanate from the area sound was made, whether from a trapped item, or from a persons steps, and make it easier to track a person through small bits of sound, but in areas where theres lots of sounds going on, it could become confusing to the phantom what sounds are actually people or are the items. Either that, or make it so the phantom has to actually attack like the lurker does to kill, and not just walk through the person.Another suggestion I would have at the moment (not knowing if/what monsters will be added as well as maps) is to have specially designed large maps that can support up to 10 players, and 2 players play monsters. Imagine them working as a team, the Lurker setting traps and turning physical right in front of people, and in their panic, they run away, attracting the attention of the Phantom or continues the chase. I feel it would be a much more intense experience for people if it were balanced properly.Overall, I feel the game has immense potential and am really excited to see the game grow.

content:
Posted: June 16, 2014
Early Access Review
								BRIEF SYNOPSIS: You can have great jump scares with this beta 3D multiplayer horror adventure where you play either one of four survivors trying to escape, or a horrifying monster attempting to kill the survivors; recommended despite bugs (see forums). * Spoilers below *GAMEPLAY REVIEW:Summary:My childhood nightmares come to life. I'm a wimp when it comes to anything horror, but the multiplayer adventurer in me as drawn me in. It is brilliant to have four different human survivors as a team versus one human-controlled monster. And the three current monsters are terrifying, along with the ten existing levels full of creepy ambiance and atmosphere.Escape is difficult but not impossible for the survivors, who need to find keys and codes to unlock and open doors and safes, use batteries to power their flashlights, grab a crowbar or hammer to smash wooden boards, and eventually escape the monster or fall victim to it. The longer it takes to complete a level, the more the survivors become insane and the more difficult it becomes to escape.In game chat:I really enjoyed using the 3d audio with a microphone headset. It makes a huge difference in the game. Everyone can hear you speaking, so if you want to keep the monster guessing use the in-game text chat (brought up with the enter key). It's also good with chatting in-between rounds in the lobby.Game play seems to favour the monsters, but smart survivors will be able to team up to outwit their pursuer to escape. Even in death, survivors can text chat with the living to give helpful hints, such as “You missed a key in the sink,” or “I have a crowbar with my body on the main floor.”Lobby:After logging in you can setup your options and either join or host your own game. Hosts can have an open game lobby or set a password to have a private game amongst friends only. Some people have complained about being kicked out of games but I think most people who want private games have figured out how to the use password now. Those of you still kicking people, stop being so lazy and use a password for your private games (May the Lurker devour your soul...). The people hosting and the people I've played with in this community have been courteous and fun to play with. Thanks people for making this game even more fun! Most people seem to be on the servers during the weekends.Life mode seems better if you are casually hosting players – people can join in whenever they feel like if there is a spot. Normal mode is more hard core with only one life to live or die with.Levels:There are currently ten levels consisting of three hotels, three asylums, a hospital (asylum set), a restaurant (hotel set), a warehouse (hotel set), and a factory. Each are different sizes and have different strategies. Some have two exits which help prevent monster camping at the exit. Some have stairs and different levels. Some have too many damn tables. Each level is creepy and atmospheric. I AM HOPING FOR GRAVEYARD TYPE LEVELS FOR A FUTURE UPDATE. There are only three different set types for levels (asylum, hotel, or factory).Survivors:There are four player controlled survivor models:Mia the emo; she appears to be Asian and wears miss-matching shoes.Scott the jockey, sporting his Eagles college jacket.Jacob the nerd; he is of African descent and a little stout.Father John the priest; he totes a Bible but it's not compelling monsters to go away.The survivors typically start in a room and have to find keys and codes to unlock doors and safes that will eventually allow them to escape from the level. The survivors are equipped with a battery burning flashlight that needs to be replenished or they will be forced to grope around in the dark. The longer the survivors take to complete a level, the more insane they will become. Others tools survivors will need include either a crowbar or a small hammer to remove boards from exit or storage doors. [A shovel is needed in the graveyard level.] - oops, sorry, don't know how that got in there... There are no weapons or way to attack the monster, which makes then all the more scary. Repeat, there is no BFG to save you!Monsters:There are currently three monsters that one player can choose to hunt down the survivors. I feel the monsters are generally well-balanced. Some people feel the Phantom is still overpowered, despite all the tweaks it has been receiving as of late. Survivors must adjust their game-play for each monster in order to escape.Mary is the scariest monster and my current favourite. She is a great monster with pretty blue eyes, but she has some posture issues. She seems well balanced with her movements and attacks. Her walk mode is a little slow, but her attack is long reaching and swift. Quick manoeuvring for survivors is the key when you hear her scream. Mary has some movement issues over objects and the Factory catwalk.The Lurker is a muscular hulk with two forms. The first form is spiritual and allows the Lurker to freely roam the level, unencumbered by doors. In this mode it can set sound traps that go off when a survivor is nearby to help it locate the players as it cannot see anyone in this form. Once the Lurker is powered up by time it can enter its physical form where it can visibly stalk and kill remaining survivors. After a while the Lurker will revert to its spiritual form where it will have to wait until it recharges and takes physical form again. The longer the Lurker remains in physical form, the longer it take to recharge in spiritual form.The Phantom is a roaming skeletal ghost (the creepiest monster for me until Mary joined) that can see survivors via sound such as the clicking of flashlights, running, or setting off a trap. Then it's either run away for the survivors and try to escape the Phantoms detection radius or get eviscerated by it. When the Phantom hears a survivor, it can see a white shadow, even through walls or different levels, of where the player is.Traps are set automatically for the Phantom and Mary, whereas setting traps is part of the Lurker's strategy. They are generally objects strewn about the level. Each trap makes a different sound to alert a monster to where a survivor is.Sound:The music is great for a horror game. Each monster has its own terrifying theme music when it appears near a survivor. Ambient sounds like footsteps, breathing, traps, and screams add to the atmosphere. The 3D audio chat really adds to the game-play; it is great to taunt the survivors as a monster. Dead players can only text chat.Insanity system:The insanity system increases game difficulty by darkening a survivor's screen to the point of complete darkness, making the flashlight flicker on and off, causing the player to hear random sounds, losing hearing, losing colour vision, having arms emerge from the ground that slow or halt a survivor's progress, randomly disabling a directional key on your keyboard, and flashing images of possessed survivors across your screen. The effects are temporary but potentially deadly.The insanity mode is a great idea and has been toned down from beta 1.0 to occur less frequently. It serves its purpose of making the game especially difficult the longer the survivors take to exit. Apparently the jump scare faces have been fixed so that they don't blind you, but I have yet to see the new effect since my game currently freezes before it occurs. I feel the jump scares are not necessary in this game. Also annoying for fair game-play is the keyboard/mouse movement disabling effect.CONCLUSION:Despite bugs being ironed out during the beta period, I feel the game is a very enjoyable if not a mildly terrifying experience. It's best played with all five people, and the up to four survivors really need to cooperate to escape from the monster. Recommended for beta and if all bugs (especially game freezing/crashing) get squashed for the retail release.Edited 2014-08-26 - [Version Beta 1.12a]

content:
Posted: March 16, 2015
												I hate to give it a no because it has so much potential. Right now the game is excessively difficult to play and unbalanced in the favor of monsters. There are two types of characters, the survivors, who search for things such as batteries (to power your limited flashlights), tools (to help you open barricades) and keys (to help you open locked doors). To open locked doors, you have to hold left click, then push or pull the door in the direction the door opens. This is cumbersome, and with all the other issues in the game, such as the extremely imprecise cursor, it is a feature of the game that really should have taken bakesat to fixing other things. Doors should just open and shut.I am a 260 pound man and I think the survivor characters run like a bunch of chain smoking grannies with rusty walkers. I could outrun them after a night of no sleep. That's saying something. Ultimately, the game has a lot of potential, but right now, the difficulty of finding the tools you need to escape, the anticlimactic escape situations, the absence of a story line and voice acting, the poor. In time the game might become playable.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
Early Access Review
								Imagine the survival-horror and puzzle solving of Amnesia but there are 4 people trying to work together and survive in a multiplayer map.  The survivors must find their way out of the map (dungeon, asylum, etc) by finding keys to open doors, find crowbars to break open secret areas and much more.  Instead of various AI monsters you have to avoid there is a fifth player who plays as a single monster who works to kill you.  One monster can walk through doors while the other one can lay traps for the survivors.  There are a few more buffs and negs to the monsters such as movement speed and one monsters 'mortal form.'  The map is randomly generated at the start of the round so no two matches feel the same.  This game is very fun and intense.  At the time of writing this it is in alpha so it is buggy for now and needs a few balance tweaks.  There are two types of monsters that players can play as and each one has their pros and cons.  Buy the 4 pack and make that friend you don't care for to much pay for it himself and kill him or her over and over again.

content:
Posted: January 7
												Damned is a flawed game with a tremendous amount of potential.The basic premise is an asymetrical multiplayer FPS horror game.  Four players play people and one person plays some sort of monster.  The monster is invincible and can kill any of the players instantly.  The players need to navigate their way through frequently labyrinthine levels full of locked doors and... well locked doors.  If the monster kills all the players, the monster wins.  If the players find the exit, the players win.  The monsters can only hunt the players at certain times in certain circumstances.  The rest of the time they are trying to keep tabs on the players if they can, and generally keep the players as scared as possible.The things about this game that I love:- As a player, because you have no real defenses of your own, the monsters are terrifying.  Seeing one always elicits an immediate and frantic attempt to escape.- The 3D attenuated sound means that the monsters can really add to the experience by acting in scary (or funny) ways.- The complicated level layouts leave lots of time for the players to get lost, get separated, be hunted, etc.  Games almost always last long enough for quite a few good scares and intense moments.The problems with this game: - Horribly buggy.  We have never had a gaming session that hasn't been marred by game crashes, freezes, etc.  It can be tricky to recover from some of these crashes, and sometimes they'll require a hard reboot.  Also, the game requires a login, and if you crash sometimes that login gets locked in a session meaning you can't rejoin for a while.- The monsters have very little to do in the periods when they aren't being a direct threat.  Sure you can "place traps", but that entails nothing more then clicking on objects.  Not particularly exciting.- The players have only one puzzle to solve.  Find the key that fits the door.  And there are no clues as to which key is for what, so not only is it a very boring puzzle, it's extremely tedious as you try every key you find on every door that's locked.  Sure, there are also boarded doors and safes, but they are still the same mechanic, it's just that the key is named "hammer", or "crowbar" or "safe code".  - The maps and monsters are terribly balanced.  Some monsters will wipe out the players very quickly.  Others will make for excellent experiences.  Some maps fit certain monsters very well, but fit other monsters very poorly.All in all I want to recommend this game, and have marked it as such.  However, it has some serious issues, and I would caution against buying it without being aware of the issues it has.

content:
Posted: March 22
Product received for free
												I got this game from a friend and we played like 2-3 rounds of it.I was a human every time (all random) and we managed to find a server with 3 more guys in it so we had a full group. This 3 guys were the only other players we found, so we joined them to maybe find out what our objective was (they had no clue as well).The objective is still not clear to me, my friend told me that we would have to look for an exit? im not sure, but the only thing i ever found was a battery, to interact with, everything else was just decoration and nothing innovative. Closed doors, random barrels stairs, sinks.. in every room on the map. QUALITY. There are a few more maps but i can imagine them all being build by the same lame structure. Even in the trailer with the girl there was NOTHING, 2 lockers and EMPTY corridors, thats pretty much every map in a nutshell.The atmosphere of this game was pretty scary at first, because i didnt know what would happen to me, only that a real player is controlling a monster, so anything could happen at any time. After a while it became annoying, because there was not much to do. The trailer makes the game look scary, and it can actually be scary, because everything can happen at any time, but it WILL be the same over and over again and i got used to one monster in the same round, so i doubt that the other 2 or 3, monster will change much about it. (One is just a statue who waits in a room and chases me when he finds me. How he works, no clue, but after a while he disappears and waits somewhere else for me)The maps are very, very limited and there is barely anything to interact with. I mean, nothing, only picking up keys and batterys. The game is full of dead ends and i was dead whenever a monster would corner me in there.Also you can do NOTHING as human, only run around and sprint for 1.5 seconds.The animations are very stiff and just a pain to look at.No hiding or anything to protect myself as human...I played demos with more content then this.All in all it was a huge disappointment. It still bothers me that the developers want 20€ for this piece of uncompleted garbage,My friend payed 6€ for both games together and it was still not worth it. Dont buy this. Seriously.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2016
nukes-viewHi all, nukes here.Damned is a great first person survival horror, played best with close friends. Four survivors are forced to try and escape, as a monster with unique abilities is trying to hunt and kill them.With a variety of eerie level designs which forces you to explore and find randomised items to escape, Damned will have you running for your life in fear as a survivor, or laughing maniacally as a monster as your closest friend screams in terror as you chase them down.I had brilliant fun playing this game with my friends, I am sure you will too.The Game PlayAs a Damned survivor your aim is to escape by finding keys, unlocking doors and finding an exit. Whether you work as a team with your friends is up to you. As there is nothing like running from something that is trying to kill you, and closing a door before your friend manages to make it.Ultimately killing your friend, although don't expect him to hold the door in the future.The monsters of Damned work differently but all have the same goal kill all survivors and stop them escaping.With four monsters to choose from each one works differently, giving different ways to hunt down your friends. Let their screams echo throughout.DifficultyThe difficulty of this game is based on the skill of the person who plays the monster and how good you are at surviving.This game also becomes easier when you start to familiarise yourself with the maps and locations of items spawns, items are still randomly spawned.A few options the host can choose to make this game more challenging such as giving survivors only one life.Controls & InterfaceGenerally keyboard and mouse is what the game is geared towards although I am aware there is partial to full controller support. (Have not tested this)AchievementsDamned has simple achievements that won't take long to unlock if you really want them.StoryThere is no story for this game or single player.Combat System Only monsters can engage in combat with claws, talons and touch. Once a survivor gets hit you die.Run, run, run don't look back.Skills & TraitsNo skill trait system.Sounds & EffectsHaunted house ambient style music keeps you immersed.GraphicsGraphics are nothing amazing, but the designs of the maps set the scene quite well.Only thing I would say that bothers me is some jump scare effects that sometimes pop and break the immersion.Random scary face, for the win. - This may have been changed.Although the lighting effects and the hands are okay although could be tweaked.MultiplayerThis game has a fantastic multiplayer, but I strongly recommend playing with friends as I found it very enjoyable this way.I can definitely say they had me running for my life. Personal Experience: - Courtesy of my friend WeaverWhen you think your safe in a room, with Mary creepily looking at you through the window as you hold onto the door hand for dear life. Suddenly Mary disappears (Randomly teleporting is one of her abilities).... Phew I am safe. ....Wait what's this, I can still hear her sinister whispering. Turning around to see her behind me I freak-out and try to escape.... I never made it out alive.As I then hear my friend laughing at me on teamspeak.Bugs - ImportantUnfortunately this game does have a few bugs here and there, some of them add to the charm but some can be a little annoying. Such as items not spawning and such.Also some rare issues of the game crashing and or not starting, make sure to verify game integrity, also check your firewall settings as this may help.I know the devs are working on fixes and updates but it seems to be a slow process.ConclusionSo overall I found this game terrifying and great to play with friends, playing a few games with random people was less immersive as I didn't know them.This game is great for a good scare and can make you jump or screaming out loud for your life. As I am sure your neighbours or someone you live with will possibly think you are being murdered in real life.If you love scare genres, par the bugs and minor issues you will love this game. I hope the developers will release more content and keep any fixes and updates coming. Or a Damned IIHope I helped, good luck.ηυĸєΜ266

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 13, 2014
												This game is still early access, so this review is subject to change/additionsDamned is basically what it says on the Tin. A survival horror game for 5 players (Maximum) where four play scavenger hunt Point A to point D item findings, and one player plays one of (Currently 3) monsters to murder your friends. Fun for everyone, especially if you have friends who enjoy screaming very loudly at your music-cue arrival. Lets get down to it.Gamplay involves item-based problem solving. Simple stuff. Find key, key goes to Locker, locker goes to safe, safe goes to kitchen, kitchen goes to crowbar, crowbar goes to wood over door, escape through door. Not always that simple, but basically always that formula. You have to find keys, unlock doors and safes, and escape out of the final door while eluding the monster player. Not always so easy.The Monster player has 3 monsters to choose from (At the time of this review) being Lurker, Phantom, and Mary. Lurker is your tall and gruesome skinless hulkbeast who spends a majority of the game in "Phase mode" which is where the player will move around quickly, phasing through doors (Cause you cant see them) and players (Who you also cant see) and setting traps. Since you can't see players, you need to use the traps to figure out their locations. Once they set one off, and it lets you phase in, you pop in and slice them to ribbons.The phantom is like a satanic stevie wonder. A floating torso who is completely blind to anyone unless they make a lot of sound. This means running, and clicking your flashlight. And getting too close. Make too much noise, and you'll show up in his vision as a white life-form that he can go maul. It's a fairly simple system, and I've nearly had it gotten around when I played him.Mary is your near-typical japanese-horror esque girl. Similar in design to popular ones like the Ring, or grudge. For a majority of the game she moves slower than a 95 year old man walking through hot tar. She also randomly teleports as a way to balance and make your life easier. You might teleport in the same room as the players, might not. You can also manually teleport, but we'll get to that in a second.Mary has the ability to enter a /frenzy/ mode when her meter (Which you dont see) fills. Stare at the players enough, and you can activate frenzy mode. a 10-15 second burst of quadrupled speed in which she screams violently, goes all scary faced and comes bullrushing you. You can also exchange a bit of the frenzy meter for another teleport, if you dont wanna wait for the freebie random one.There are about 12+ stages right now, with the most recent (At the time of this review) being a forest/camping area. The game does have some flaws, like optimization issues, data leaks, and minor coding bugs. Updates are also somewhat slow, but when they come around they are very nice. Running on my toaster I get about 25-30 frames in a map. Apparently a high-end gets about the same, due to optimization issues. It happens.I can't really rate it with a number right now, but I am giving it a yes. It's a nice game, for a beta.

content:
Posted: May 1, 2015
												This is proof that a game can have co-op/multiplayer and still be incredibly scary.There's a good variety of maps in the game, and the developers seem to add more and more every once in a while. There's a lot of variety in the monsters. One person gets to be the monster while the others are humans trying to escape. The monster player can choose from a handful of monster types, including a blind ghost who can only see by sounds (like sprinting, opening/closing doors, etc.), a ghost girl that's basically Samara from The Ring, and a large brute creature that can turn invisible.Sadly, the game seems to be dying. The last few nights that I've tried to play, I haven't been able to get into a single match. There's always a private server with 2 or 3 players in it (the game is 5 player max), and then one sole person sitting in a server, but no one else joins (and 1v1 isn't very exciting in this game).It's a great game, and by far the best multiplayer horror game (White Noise Online is the only other one I can think of, though), but while I do recommend it, I only recommend buying it if it's on sale (meaning there'll be more people playing it while it's on sale) or if you have at least two or three other friends wanting to also play it with you.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2014
Early Access Review
								I know I've only played 2 hours, but it's an alpha and currently there isn't much new past 2 hours.This game is fun as hell. Disclaimer: I play with a set group of friends who are guaranteed to communicated well & effectively, your experience with random public players will likely be less than satisfactory.This game is really fun, especially when you know everybody. When you're being hunted by the monster you get frantic looking for keys, and when you're the monster it's amazing just trying to plan out when you're going to get survivors or if you just want to scare them for a little bit.Since this is an alpha, there are a few glitches. Some people have issues with alt-tabbing, other times players apparently can't connect. There is also the occassional crash (I haven't crashed or experienced any bugs except the following one). The only game-breaking bug (as in you have to go to a new round) is when you spawn in a room and cannot get out or if you cannot continue, however this is extremely rare.This game shows a lot of promise and is currently extremely fun. There is proximity chat which can be hilarious when the lurker uses it!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is very very fun.  And gameplay is simple yet very complex.There are 4 humans trying to escape a building.  Throughout each map are keys and other items that the humans need to find in order to escape.  The placement of the items and paths randomize on each map so you have a different experience each time.  As a human you use a combination of left mouse button and mouse movements to open and close doors and drawers.  You also get a flashlight and you can sprint for short periods of time (with a slow regen of sprint).  You can't fight the monsters; all you can do is run, hide and die.There are 2 types of monsters with very different abilities.  The basic mission for the monster is to kill all the humans which is often easier said than done.This game is very fun to play as people will regularly freak out and scream sounding like a little girl.  GET IT NOW!

content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
												Do you like horror puzzle games without weapons like Amnesia, Penumbra, or Outlast? Do you like co-op games like Left 4 Dead, or Payday?Then this great but limited game of cat and mouse might be for you. Playing as one of 4 survivors working together (or against each other) is terrifying especially when players start dropping like flies. Playing as one of 3 selectable monsters is extremely fun if you've read the guides to learn how they work because each one has different strengths/weaknesses and the game doesn't tell you anything. Downsides:Limited monsters to selectVery small amount of players on at any given timePoor server browser with no ability to filter full or private matches (and no single player)Prone to crashes and players drop out of matches too often, causing everyone else to leave. Some graphical imperfections that take away from the experienceStill love it, and would like to see the game progress in future.

												UhNot too sure what to write here so heres a recipe for Pancakes insteadIngredients:1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour3 tablespoons sugar1 tablespoon baking powder1/4 teaspoon salt1/8 teaspoon freshly ground nutmeg2 large eggs, at room temperature1 1/4 cups milk, at room temperature1/2 teaspoon pure vanilla extract3 tablespoons unsalted butter, plus more as neededNow to make it1. In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, sugar, baking powder, salt, and nutmeg.2. In another bowl, beat the eggs and then whisk in the milk and vanilla.3. Melt the butter in a large cast iron skillet or griddle over medium heat.4. Whisk the butter into the milk mixture. Add the wet ingredients to the flour mixture, and whisk until a thick batter is just formed5. Keeping the skillet at medium heat, ladle about 1/4 cup of the batter onto the skillet, to make a pancake. Make 1 or 2 more pancakes, taking care to keep them evenly spaced apart. Cook, until bubbles break the surface of the pancakes, and the undersides are golden brown, about 2 minutes. Flip with a spatula and cook about 1 minute more on the second side. Serve immediately or transfer to a platter and cover loosely with foil to keep warm. Repeat with the remaining batter, adding more butter to the skillet as needed.6. Procedure for adding fruit to pancakes: Once the bubbles break the surface of the pancakes, scatter the surface with sliced or diced fruit, or chocolate chips, nuts, etc. Flip with a spatula and cook for 1 minute more, being careful not to burn toppings.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 15, 2014
												In Damned, four people play as survivors and one as a spooky monster. There are three monsters implemented so far to choose from, each with their own unique strengths and weaknesses. The survivors collect keys and batteries and try to open enough doors to get to the exit. A very simple premise to a game that can be loads of fun, but also equally annoying when you meet someone who just uses the monster to wipe everyone out in the first minute.Damned is a game about chilling fear, amazing atmosphere and occasional jump scares. I think a lot of people underestimate the value of stalking a completely frightened prey, instead of killing it immediately. It’s priceless. I’ve seen things in this game that only happen in the best Horror movies, and have left me spooked to death.Let’s be clear, it’s not perfect. There are still numerous bugs, sometimes the map or a character will get bugged and you won’t be able to progress. Is it still worth the money? For the full price, maybe (simply because it's buggy and laggy). For the 50% discount that happens pretty much every month, definitely.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
												I have less than an hour on this game, and I have already got a huge problem with it. Let me just say I think that this game could be VERY good. But at the moment? It's unplayable! Before even getting into the game I had to battle with a server. I can't click leave lobby, I can't click choose a character and I can't even click start a game. My only option was to join someone elses server... There I also couldn't click leave or choose a character. So I went into the game as a random character. The 'helpful text' flashes up and disappears before you have a chance to read it and understand anything. Other than that (which isn't very useful anyway) you don't get any kind of tutorial, nothing else will tell you how to play the game. Because of this I died the second I entered the game - and let me clarify this was a server with new players on it.It activated my microphone, so I was talking to my boyfriend at the time of playing and random people could hear me talk!! I'm not happy about this!! This should be changed!! I purchased a 4-pack for me, my boyfriend and two of our friends, and I am not happy. I wish I hadn't. Although the game looks very good (as I've already said) it's just totally unplayable right now!! I haven't even been able to see who any of the characters are, what any of the monsters do or what the actual objective us (although I guess it's purely to survive and not stab yourself from pure frustration).Don't buy this game, unless it's on a REALLY good sale. Then don't play it. DO NOT PLAY until this game is ACTUALLY finally fixed. It's just impossible.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2015
												Damned Pros and cons and overall thoughtsDamned is a fun, multiplayer survival horror game where 4 people (Or less) play as survivors while the 5th player chooses one of 4 monsters and has to try and kill the survivors, each monster being unique in it's own way.===Pros*Cool Music/Sound Effects*Allows Co-Op which most horror games do not have*Nice Push/Pull system with doors and drawers. (Like an Amnesia: The Dark Descent)*Unique Character models and graphics*Tons of maps*Unique and easy to pick up mechanics*Simple hosting/connecting to friends*Good Sp00ks with insanity effects*Literally like goosebumps the game. (The goosebumps theme fits so well it's not even funny)===Cons*Some maps and monster combinations make the game extremely difficult or too easy*Some monsters are more overpowered than others*Some maps are very hard to find keys on. Ex: Black Lake*Performance problems on the highest settings (And I have a decent gaming computer)===All around very fun and unique game experience. 10/10Will play again.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 14, 2015
												-----------------------------------------------------------------Damned-----------------------------------------------------------------Damned is a multiplayer horror game, where 4 players play as survivors and 1 player plays as a monster. in the same vain as Dead by daylight, but one of the differences is that Damned takes place inside a house/asylum, while DBD takes place mostly outside. another difference is the gameplay is Vastly different, so much so that you cant even compare them. for instance, Damned is much, much, much, much worse. The controls are clunky and uncomfortable. And the door controls are HORRIBLE. they try to be like amnesia, in the way you click and drag, but they somehow screwed it up. its unresponsive and when you finally do get it, it goes a bit too far and you get stuck. Waiting for the monster to come and eat you up.Some good stuff is that the monsters powers and model are very well done and well thought out.but thats not enough to save this game from its rating.-----------------------------------------------------------------3/10-----------------------------------------------------------------

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 23, 2015
												Absolutely a fun game with friends-- especially if they have microphones. Three types of monsters, each with their own playstyle that the survivors will have to adapt to in order to survive.But surviving is not enough, as the longer you take, the less sane you become. You not only imagine sounds that others cannot hear, but you see the faces of the dead, your flashlight flickers without cause, your hearing becomes impaired, and worse.Your ultimate objective is to find a key to unlock another door that hopefully has the one key you need to unlock your only escape. Be sure to check each drawer, stove, counter top, table, and bucket, because the keys-- and batteries for your flashlight-- could be anywhere, just like the monster.Did you see Mary when you turned that corner? Hopefully not, because that means she saw you. Did that clock make a loud noise as you passed it? Hope you are just going crazy, because that means the Lurker found you. Did that strange apparition spook you as you turned the corner? Hope not, because any noise you make as a result brings it right to you.While the game itself is extremely fun with friends who have microphones and with a monster who would rather toy with you than kill you right away, there is a noticeable lack of optimization. I used to be able to run this game well enough 45+ FPS normally on my mid-end system, but it suddenly dropped to 15 and less. Many solutions did not work, but one did; uninstall, reboot, reinstall.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
												Do you like horror puzzle games without weapons like Amnesia, Penumbra, or Outlast? Do you like co-op games like Left 4 Dead, or Payday?Then this great but limited game of cat and mouse might be for you. Playing as one of 4 survivors working together (or against each other) is terrifying especially when players start dropping like flies. Playing as one of 3 selectable monsters is extremely fun if you've read the guides to learn how they work because each one has different strengths/weaknesses and the game doesn't tell you anything. Downsides:Limited monsters to selectVery small amount of players on at any given timePoor server browser with no ability to filter full or private matches (and no single player)Prone to crashes and players drop out of matches too often, causing everyone else to leave. Some graphical imperfections that take away from the experienceStill love it, and would like to see the game progress in future.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
												UhNot too sure what to write here so heres a recipe for Pancakes insteadIngredients:1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour3 tablespoons sugar1 tablespoon baking powder1/4 teaspoon salt1/8 teaspoon freshly ground nutmeg2 large eggs, at room temperature1 1/4 cups milk, at room temperature1/2 teaspoon pure vanilla extract3 tablespoons unsalted butter, plus more as neededNow to make it1. In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, sugar, baking powder, salt, and nutmeg.2. In another bowl, beat the eggs and then whisk in the milk and vanilla.3. Melt the butter in a large cast iron skillet or griddle over medium heat.4. Whisk the butter into the milk mixture. Add the wet ingredients to the flour mixture, and whisk until a thick batter is just formed5. Keeping the skillet at medium heat, ladle about 1/4 cup of the batter onto the skillet, to make a pancake. Make 1 or 2 more pancakes, taking care to keep them evenly spaced apart. Cook, until bubbles break the surface of the pancakes, and the undersides are golden brown, about 2 minutes. Flip with a spatula and cook about 1 minute more on the second side. Serve immediately or transfer to a platter and cover loosely with foil to keep warm. Repeat with the remaining batter, adding more butter to the skillet as needed.6. Procedure for adding fruit to pancakes: Once the bubbles break the surface of the pancakes, scatter the surface with sliced or diced fruit, or chocolate chips, nuts, etc. Flip with a spatula and cook for 1 minute more, being careful not to burn toppings.

Early Access Review
								Awesome game,The same fear levels & enjoyment as with Slender Man, The only difference is, it's one of YOU who is the monster!...The only thing wrong with this game I can see at the moment is the player pool!...Where is everybody? This game has so much to offer, yet so little people are interested.Maybe they should try giving a free for 24-48 hour opportunity.The maps are lovely & spooky, the monster is really creepy looking, and theres more monsters to come!,the music drives you slightly insane, and there is nothing worse than being on your own for too long.I'm really looking forward to this new insanity system, I think it will really give players a chill while being the last survivor!I hope to see more of you creeping down the halls!Fully recommend this game!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
												Do you like horror puzzle games without weapons like Amnesia, Penumbra, or Outlast? Do you like co-op games like Left 4 Dead, or Payday?Then this great but limited game of cat and mouse might be for you. Playing as one of 4 survivors working together (or against each other) is terrifying especially when players start dropping like flies. Playing as one of 3 selectable monsters is extremely fun if you've read the guides to learn how they work because each one has different strengths/weaknesses and the game doesn't tell you anything. Downsides:Limited monsters to selectVery small amount of players on at any given timePoor server browser with no ability to filter full or private matches (and no single player)Prone to crashes and players drop out of matches too often, causing everyone else to leave. Some graphical imperfections that take away from the experienceStill love it, and would like to see the game progress in future.

number of helpful: 10 of 20 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 18, 2014
												This game is clearly a cash in on other  a-synchronous multiplayer games being conceptualized off of popular board games. 1 monster vs. 4 survivors is a great concept that this one doesn’t fully realized.The monsters are fine but the only object for the survivors is to find keys to open doors. THAT IS ALL. Me and my friends would voluntarily sit and do nothing as the monster to find all of the keys or get to the end. After 2 hours we gave up. It very much feels like a game that cannot be won on the survivor’s side because the win state and objective for them wasn’t fully realized.The maps are either too narrow or too large and all of the environments feel recycled and with irrelevant obstacles in them.If this concept excites you play board games with this premise or wait for “Last Year”. Which this game feels like it was trying to beat to release

content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
												UhNot too sure what to write here so heres a recipe for Pancakes insteadIngredients:1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour3 tablespoons sugar1 tablespoon baking powder1/4 teaspoon salt1/8 teaspoon freshly ground nutmeg2 large eggs, at room temperature1 1/4 cups milk, at room temperature1/2 teaspoon pure vanilla extract3 tablespoons unsalted butter, plus more as neededNow to make it1. In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, sugar, baking powder, salt, and nutmeg.2. In another bowl, beat the eggs and then whisk in the milk and vanilla.3. Melt the butter in a large cast iron skillet or griddle over medium heat.4. Whisk the butter into the milk mixture. Add the wet ingredients to the flour mixture, and whisk until a thick batter is just formed5. Keeping the skillet at medium heat, ladle about 1/4 cup of the batter onto the skillet, to make a pancake. Make 1 or 2 more pancakes, taking care to keep them evenly spaced apart. Cook, until bubbles break the surface of the pancakes, and the undersides are golden brown, about 2 minutes. Flip with a spatula and cook about 1 minute more on the second side. Serve immediately or transfer to a platter and cover loosely with foil to keep warm. Repeat with the remaining batter, adding more butter to the skillet as needed.6. Procedure for adding fruit to pancakes: Once the bubbles break the surface of the pancakes, scatter the surface with sliced or diced fruit, or chocolate chips, nuts, etc. Flip with a spatula and cook for 1 minute more, being careful not to burn toppings.

content:
Posted: October 16, 2013
Early Access Review
								Damned takes the best parts of TTT and mashes it together with Prophunt, Darkest Days, and The Hidden. It's legitimately terrifying, and has randomly generated maps and objectives. A player is randomly selected to be the monster, and each monster requires a different playstyle both to hunt, and to dodge.Objectives are random and strewn across the map, but scripted  in such a way that that requires you to cover the entire map to escape. You'll never spawn in a room you can't escape from.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 21, 2016
												This is basicly Dead by Daylight but it's actually scary. In all honesty though, this is one of the most wonderful games I have ever had the pleasure of playing. It is in my opinion, the paramount of Multiplayer Horror and it is one of the few in that Genre to be honestly scary. The game would be very close to perfect, but if I said it was I would be lieing. There is ofcourse as with any game, the occasional bug and at times it may be hard to find an open game for you to play due to the occasional lack of games and players. But the game itself is simply impecceble, the atmosphere instills genuine feelings of suspense and fear and the monsters are as ingenious as they are terrifying. And this game accomplishes all of that on Multiplayer. It's a shame it isnt more popular but honestly; buy this game. It's a must have. You'll be looking for keys for weeks!

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 16, 2016
												The game includes a community which, doesn't make an aweful lot of sense.  They mic spam, complain endlessly, and kick you if you kill them as the monster for most of the games I've been in.   Atop of that, sometimes it can just be incredibly boring wandering aimlessly not knowing where the humans are for significant periods of time.  I initially gotten the game before it came to steam, and was rather into it at first; but I never really could sit down and play it much ever since till recently.Other issues I have with it, the sound effects are bad, the music is bad, the hit detection is bad, the server choices is garbage, as well as the active community I've encountered, and the gameplay is significantly below what you'd expect out of a $20 game.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 20, 2015
												Damned is a survival horror game where Humans are trapped inside a map for example a asylum and have to escape. While theyre trying to find keys to escape theyre not alone, Theyre being hunted by monsters (Lurker, Phantom or Mary) All monsters have advantages and disadvantages. For example mary is a very slow moving character but when you stare at humans for a certain amount of time she will be given the option to go into frenzy mode meaning she will then be really fast and then will be able to kill the humans. The goal is to escape as humans or to kill evey human thats trap inside as a monster.This game is alot of fun especially with groups of friends in a skype or steam group call which can make games insanly fun and alot of funny moments. I would give this game a 9/10 and definatly recomend it to anyone.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 12, 2015
												This is my first review but i hope this helps other people see how awesome this game is. I know I have only played this game for like 2 hours but thats all you need for such an awesome game however there were some parts that were annoying but wasnt enough to destroy the game play.Outside of gameplay:+ I experienced that the cursor was guite laggy (slight stutters)+ If you did not put full screen on your cursor could not click the side options (so put fullscreen on)+ Sometimes Alt+tab would glitch my resolution or just crash the game so I just avoided that.Gameplay:+ Fun to play (if you have friends)+ The maps are good but if there is not time limit it can get a bit boring as some of the maps are big making it hard and iritating for anyone playing the monster.+ The monsters are cool and its nice they have some handi caps so they are not too OP + I feel there should be more than 3 monsters but the game is still tons of fun just with 3 because they all have their own unique ability.+ More monsters to choose from would be nice+ If normal characters had special abilities assigned to them would be awesome.Overall, this game is fun even for someone like me who hates these kind of games but its just a great way fro you and your friends to engage with each other, if you like thrillers/jumpscares.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 22, 2014
												Can't recommend it at this point in time. It's got some real entertaining moments, but there are too many little things that ruin it. The game is heavily biased in favor of the monsters. It's very rare for the survivors to actually win the round. The maps are garbage and cluttered with too much stuff that gets in the way. And the biggest issue is that when people leave the game, which they do frequently, the character they were playing as goes away, but late joiners can't replace them. So usually the game quickly turns into a 1v2 instead 1v5. Maybe they'll improve it in the future. Like I said, it's fun. Anyone who wants a quick fix survival horror game will enjoy it for a while, but it's got too many problems to last.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 5, 2014
												This game has great potential. My friends and I enjoyed a couple of play throughs, but it quickly lost its appeal. The monsters lack a lot of animation and are more of jump scares than anything. Monsters from other games have more animations and scares than this, even for other indie games. It looks more like stiff zombie monsters gliding towards you. If they had more animations and better sound, then I would easily recommend this game. It honestly feels like the devs halfassed it and put it out just to see how it went, after that they barely improve anything. In the end, if you enjoy cheap thrills and playing with friends, this game works for you. But if you want something worth your time and your friends, then don't buy this game, especially not for $20.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 7, 2014
												Unifinished and frustrating.Once you're in the game: it's amazing. As a survivor, you're scrambling, looking for the keys out of the haunted area while freaking yourself out as every sound and odd sight could be sign of the monster coming to kill you in one hit.As a monster, it's an incredibly fun game of hide and seek, where you're trying to get in the head of survivors and figure out where they're gonna be, Monsters are slow, so kills are almost always accomplished by laying out an ambush.The problem is it crashes and bugs out so often, usually leaving you hanging on a screen with no notion of what's happening. I figure about 25% of my time playing this game is spent dealing with crashes, bugs, and looking for viable online games to join. This game should still be listed as Early Access, caveat emptor.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 7, 2014
												If you're the kind of person who gets frustrated by bugs preventing you from playing 50% of the time, please wait until you try Damned. Otherwise you'll get to enjoy 10-15 minutes at a time of a fun, engaging experience trying to outrun a creepy monster that makes you afraid of even using your flashlight.Except, then you die, you try to find another lobby to keep playing..... aaaaaand you crash/freeze.In all of 1 hour's play, my personal experience was:- Multiple "Server down for maintenance" messages preventing connection.- Multiple "Your account is already in use" messages when trying to reconnect after a crash.- Connected to lobbies without seeing anyone when the player count is above zero.- Connection causes a crash.- Game load causes a freeze. Arriving in a game right after load = also a freeze.- Graphics flickers on older (3 year-old) systems, really affects the experience negatively (I was on a LAN with a friend whose computer is not powerful enough to play this simple game well).Get past the above and the game is fun, although so short, it's always a gamble as to whether you'll be able to reconnect without a crash or a freeze and play for longer than one session.I'll edit this if and when they fix the bugs... until then, will not be touching it again.

content:
Posted: March 14, 2016
												The game is quite fun. However, just as other players have suggested, some of the monsters need to be better balanced. Some monsters are way too OP (Phantom and Lurker especially) while the others (May and Fallen) are very hard to play with. I like the idea behind Fallen especially, but only having 7 seconds to attack a running player at walking speed after spending 5+ minutes trying to get energy is taxing on the fun. I am also slightly concerned about the price of the game given the amount of content that it has and also how the product itself appears in its current state. There is much potential to this game as it is very unique in that it gives a personal horror experience that is fun with your friends (which you can have up to five of them playing including yourself). However, in its current state, it is not worth $20. I got the game on sale for around $7 and I don't feel I wasted money, however, if I had paid $20 for it, I may have been slightly disappointed. I think $10 would be a fair price for the game in it's current state. Some suggestions that I have personally is adding some new monsters, like maybe a clown (an omage to Pennywise from IT), warewolf, alien (like alien vs predator)... the more options the better. That goes for the survivors as well. While there may only be 4 survivors total in a given game, giving more characters too choose from would be awesome. There is only one female to choose from in the list of survivors, while there could be an all male team, or an all female team. Giving more options allows players to connect better through the character they choose. Another critique is that some of the locations are identical. While there are plenty of locations to choose from, the hotels look very similar to each other, and so do the hospitals. It takes away each location's uniqueness. The forest and the diner and warehouse are good locations. But if there are going to be multiple hotels and multiple hospitals it would be wise to consider making them vastly unique from each other. Overall the game is great, but I would say that the biggest con is that it is overpriced given the amount of conent that it has. When this game is on sale, I recommend getting it, as it is fun to play with friends.

												A fun, yet bone-chilling experience which will easily give you the shakes, especially when you can't tell where certain "enemies" are. -And despite the fact that the enemy is controlled by a Player, it makes the experience MUCH more difficult.Damned offers a small selection of characters and monsters to play as, one player will be chosen or chooses a monster character. The rest choose which of the four characters (hiding their names to prevent spoilers.) they would like to play as.With chilling scenarios and levels, filled with multiple "traps" which spring to life when close to them, the monster could be anywhere, and could start their rampage against the survivors in order to prevent their escape. I suggest this game to anyone who's willing to frighten themselves or... play a horror game worthy of clothing change. highly recommended XD

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 1, 2015
												Do NOT buy this game.Go look at the forums please. I got this game on sale a while back and it was a big mistake.The idea of the game is fun, but the idea has been done much better on other games. This game rarely gets updates. The community on the game is not high. The monster selection is low and the surviver selection is low. If you play one to two matches with each monster then you will get the game. When the monster you would think it is fun, but no it isn't. As the monster you spend most of the time running around hoping to bump into someone. As a survivor you run around hoping to find a key. You will only get a fast, maybe interesting, game if both monster and players know the map by heart and memory and where stuff tends to be located. Sometimes the game will bug and you can't pick up a key you need or open a door even if you have the right key. Also, if you are playing and the person as the monster leaves the game your entire game is ruined and you are ♥♥♥♥ed. The game wont end automatically nor will it put someone as the monster like any good game mechanic would do.The game itself is really buggy. The engine this runs on is apparently poop so thats a thing.Here is their official website:http://www.9heads.com/games/damned/This link should illustrate the quality they put out. Here is a quote from the devs, "9heads also uses free programming libraries and engine such as Ogre3D and Bullet Physics proving that you can achieve very nice results with exceptional free/open-source stuff out there."

content:
Posted: October 31, 2015
												It took me a while to get this game to work since i had the issue where my FPS would not go higher than 15 FPS but after some tweaking and one good reboot later i got it to run smoothly and i enjoyed the game alot. It is specially fun if you play with your friends and i'd imagine that one can easily spend some time playing this game during weekends for jumpscares and laughs. This game should not be taken too seriosly since the survivor goals tend to feel a little bit tedious and frustrating at times. Clearly it is much more fun to be the monster than a survivor but if you are playing with friends it really does not matter what happens.The game itself is buggy and still as it seems a work in progress but if you can make it run good you are about to have some good time.So i would say 3/5 for the overall experience and 5/5 for the spooky atmosphere and that is where this game is at its strongest. I strongly recommend trying this one out specially if it's on sale,

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19, 2016
												Cannot recommend this enough for a group of friends if you can buy it for all 4-5 people. Even 3 if you have to. Great time. Maps and graphic optimisation drag the game down a bit, there are a couple that seem identical, if not deserve to just be merged into a bigger one because they look very similar in terms of color, style etc. Graphic optimisation here is tough. Not something you should worry about though because the graphics aren't much even on max, and you aren't here for that anyway. The horror is good enough to give this game about 7/10. Above average and greatly worthy of your money and time if you can round up at least 3 people including yourself. If not, you're not a big loss as you can always find good people to play with and the population of lobbys never seems to have decreased. I do feel however that the monsters you can play as, need very VERY close watching from the developers. There looks like there might start to be this trend of: monsters that are just out to kill, not scare the players. This is why I fear the Lurker more than any other monster in the game, because killing the survivors in this game isn't the prime focus, it's more of a balance between wanting to scare them too.I want people to note that the game's soundtrack is by far one of the best I've seen in a while. For a small time composer, it definetly in my opinion rivals the soundtracks in bigger ones, because the composer (Matt Collins, whom if you search for the Damned soundtrack on youtube, you can find) has just a vast knowledge of how to orchestrate such dynamic, classic and grand pieces.. pieces I hope to see more of, but I doubt I will. Quality soundtracks are hard to come by, not every game's complete soundtrack is actually worth listening to. That being said, please give this game a try if you can gather 2 friends to play with, I promise you're in for a treat. And please remember to note down and give credit to Matt Collins for the game's score, he's talented and you'll see.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2015
												Damned can be a tough sell, and for good reason. Back when I bought it, sitting in a lobby for over a minute without the host starting the game basically guaranteed hard crashes for all involved. This has been (mostly) fixed, the game will still randomly kick people for no reason, and isn't very well optimized, but if playing with people you know you'll be hard pressed to find a better multiplayer horror experience when everything DOES work.Gameplay:The game is multiplayer slender with amnesia click-and-hold door controls and a battery/flashlight system that would make Jim Sterling cry. You find keys (rather than notes) and use them to open doors to find more keys until you escape, all while being hunted by one of the various monsters (played by a real person). Each monster has their own little twist on gameplay, and by far the most tense moments of the game are when you're limited in where you can travel (no keys) and don't know which monster's playstyle to counter.That's what the gameplay is, but is it fun?: Yes. Play. Damned. With. Friends. Hop in a VC, que it up, and make the monster mute himself except for the occasional brag directly after scoring a kill. You'll be amazed how quickly you can betray someone, locking them out of a room and leaving them to die in order to ensure you stay alive. You'll feel genuine relief when you cycle keys as a team to finally open that last exit door. Resource management with batteries usually feels like a tacked-on timekill mechanic, but in Damned you have to share those resources amongst 4 people, which adds to the urgency quite effectively.Playing as the monster is a blast too. Sometimes you'll get a series of bad ports as Mary, or noone will hit your traps on Lurker, but setting up a legit jumpscare makes it all worth it. My friends and I have tons of stories along the lines of "remember that time I made [friend] scream like a little ♥♥♥♥♥?" Very few games give you that opportunity.Graphics:Meh. Mary and Fallen work well because they are meant to look stiff and plodding, but lurker looks like the monster from "Boogeyman," and only will make you jump if he pops up right on your♥♥♥♥♥(which he often does). Character models are functional, as are animations. Environments are sufficiantly mood-supporting, but a LOT of the levels are "re-arranged assets from our asylum level." The most important thing is that the graphics rarely detract from the horror experience.Audio: Absolutely essential to have a good headset in order to get the full experience with this game. Most monsters set "traps" by interacting with objects in the environment that give off a sound que when the players pass by them. There is no worse feeling than stumbling through a hallway and triggering 3 or 4 traps in close succession, basically ensuring the monster knows exactly where you are. Ambient sound when the monster is close or is attacking further crank up the intensity, and the plinking minimalism of the rest of the audio just accents these bombastic moments even further.Overall: 6/10, 8/10 with lobby of friends. If you can, buy it on sale or in a 4-pack with friends pitching in, but $20 is a relatively fair price on its own.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2014
												Very suspensful gameplay, even as just me and one other friend. The AI doesn't seem to work 100% (once that is sorted out, god help the solo-artists) but the ambient sounds and use of music is very impressive. It certainly creates an immersive atmosphere that makes the game incredibly unique. Not for the faint of heart, some of those that are easily scared will probably not fair very well after playing a round with Mary! But nevertheless, it is an incredible game that has got loads of potential! The fact you can't do anything, even jump makes the game so much more surreal. It's survival horror, without the killing and with more fear factor than you can imagine!

content:
Posted: June 12, 2015
												The sensibility or insensitivity of a human, often considered with regard to a particular kind of stimulus, is the strength of the feeling it results in, in comparison with the strength of the stimulus. The concept applies to physical as well as emotional feeling. Stimulus may consist of any or all types of stimuli, including political, nationalistic, religious, physical, mental, emotional, etc. In the political sense, perception of and reaction to stimuli is often inculcated by - and for the benefit of - power holders.Sensibility of explosives is the degree to which an explosive can be initiated by impact, heat, or friction.Sensibility, along with stability and brisance are three of the most significant properties of explosives that affect their use and application. All explosive compounds have a certain amount of energy required to initiate. If an explosive is too sensible it may go off accidentally. A safer explosive is less sensible and will not explode if accidentally dropped or mishandled. However, such explosives are more difficult to initiate intentionally.The sensibility of an electronic device, such as a communications system receiver, or detection device, such as a PIN diode, is the minimum magnitude of input signal required to produce a specified output signal having a specified signal-to-noise ratio, or other specified criteria.

content:
Posted: October 31, 2015
												This game is very fun, though the fun is shortlived. This isn't the game's fault though, the game is very interesting and unique, but the graphics are a little on the low side and the community is rather small. I highly recommend that if/when you play this, you gather a group of friends. A key part of this game is exploration; you have to run around the area to collect keys and batteries for your flashlight. There are cabinets and drawers you can open, and each building has a nice theme and design to it, The monsters are all unique and are each equally fun to play as. The trap system might take a little bit of time to get used to, but the audial cues are easy to hear.As a human, your character has no effect other than aesthetic. Being the black guy doesn't mean you will die first.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
												Game is hilarious, scary and most of all, fun! I'm only 6 hours in at the time of this review. It definitely has some bugs, most obvious is crashes at map load. It seems like sometimes you can wait 2-5 minutes and the map will load but someone or someones will always leave at that point. Sometimes the maps load within 10 seconds. Not sure what the deal is. I'm sure it'll be patched. Make sure you report bugs! I bought this game on sale during the christmas sale and honestly would have given full price for it. I'm having a blast.Gameplay wise seems decently balanced except when it's 1vs1 as mary. It seems like it can be impossible sometimes. Maybe I need a better strategy? Still a thumbs up!Thanks for the fun!

number of helpful: 15 of 32 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6, 2014
Early Access Review
								Am I seriously missing something here?I'm not having a whole ton of fun with game. Tons of bugs and glitches everywhere, really bad performance issues. There is no tutorial or anything to help you, well you wont really need any help because all your gonna be doing through the whole game is PICKING UP KEYS AND UNLOCKING DOORS!!!!! Where is the variety guys? C'mon....The maps are decent but not too special, and how come being a monster just really sucks!?! You would think that you would feel pretty cool being a monster but in this GAME you feel so cheap and pathetic. I was hoping you could do many cool things as a monster like trigger things, make people hallucinate and like fly around and drop in right behind a dude and scare the living daylights out of him. BUT NO! You can't do that, well atleast from my playthroughs I couldn't. As a monster in this game, you run around the area searching for people for hours and hours and hitting them then in one hit, they're dead. Very misleading... I wasn't frightened one bit in this game, the only thing I could say that scared me much was the freaking music that plays when a person is running away from you while your the monster, it just suddenly pops in, scaring the bajeezus outta you. But one poor decision that I hate in this game is that when your the lurker, you can't see anybody until you manifest. I find it very stupid but some people might disagree with me. Only my opinionAll I can say left about this game is that the premise of it sounds incredible but the dev's executed it poorly. I know it's in a earlier stage of development but still feels like a very VERY earlier version of the game that the dev's should only have. PLEASE DEVELOPERS LISTEN OUT!!! Sorry for being harsh but please change some of these decisions that you've made, it would definitely change my thoughts about this a lot. Wait people, till these get fixed, I just can't recommend just yet.

number of helpful: 4 of 10 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 16, 2014
Early Access Review
								Unplayable.The potential is there- when and if you can connect to a game. However, this is seemingly impossible. There are maybe 3 hosted games at most at any given time- and there's a good chance only one of them is public (the full one.) Hosting a game is a futile gesture because no one is playing, no one is joining, and you can't play a game alone.I tried, and I ran around as a ghost with no one to scare or kill for 10 minutes. After I exited the game, Damned didn't understand that I couldn't die (as the ghost,) and therefore couldn't disconnect from the server... ever. It took me 45 minutes to get back to the lobby and then only after restarting my computer, which isn't really a viable option to use in order to shut down/restart the game. Especially a game which requires so much restarting to begin with. This isn't a beta, it's complete undeveloped and broken. The concept gets a gold star, though.
