content:
Posted: November 6, 2014
												This might very well be the very worst Steam game I have ever played. One hour tops is all it takes to see every single detail this game has to offer. Nothing can compare to the disappointment of the moment of finally getting far enough to get the hammer or crowbar (did I mention this game is nearly impossible for the survivors to win?) only to find out that they aren't weapons, they're just glorified keys, used only for opening doors. This game has no spark of creativity, and no loving touch at all, it's just half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥garbage with as little actual content as physically possible, in the form of a barely playable game. Even managing that, the game still is riddled with bugs. The fact that this game is being sold for 20 dollars on Steam is an insult to cheaper games that vastly outshine it, and an insult to the customer, who won't get more than an afternoon out of it. I didn't even buy this game, I got it as a gift from a friend, and even I'm insulted.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2015
You've gotta ask yourselves who is f*cking who for RockPaperShotgun/Kotaku and Eurogamer to recommend this piece of sh*t game.  Gamergate,yo! ******DONT BUY THIS GAME.****  Maybe at a sale where's its like 1 euro.. maybe. I bought the pack and for 5 a piece.. Yea haha not worth it. The gamer experience, you may encounter when playing this game.Start up game, have a tiny window. Go to settings, selecting 1920x1080 does not mean fullscreen apparantly. Drag window after you manage to unstick your mouse. Select 'Full screen' aaand- CRASH.  Looking promising already. When killing the program dont kill the 'Game' kill the other 'Game' in your programs, killing the first one doesnt solve jack sh*t. Restart the game, oh! Full screen! .. But why is the image so small? Check Gamma settings, drag it ALL the way up to high in order to see all the individual slabs of gray, go back to the home screen and .. Woa, there was another image here? No, nope, its one image, just dark as f*ck which made you think 3/4 of your screen is just black by default. Alright! Initial grievances are forgiven and forgotten, lets do this sh*t! Start a game, looking for the lobby created by a friend. Er... its here... SOMEWHERE... FOUND IT! Locked the lobby with a password so we can be noobs amongst friends. Fill in password... Nothing happens.. Did I misspell it? I guess I did, lets try again.. Nope.. I spelled it right but it wont let me in. Its not even giving me a 'this aint the password, you fool', the password screen just poofs .. Did I crash again? Oh, nope, and you can start your search for that one specific lobby all over again. Restart the game. Alright, all in Lobby, lets do this. First impressions of the ingame enviroment. This is dark as f*ck! Where's my flashlight? Its not F, not E... Where dafuq is it? Right click?! What? .. Oh okay then. Picking up items, E? Nope. Left click. Opening doors, E? ... No.. more clicking. Well, not so much clicking as dragging apparantly. Okay I got keys, I got batteries, dont know what the hell is going on but lets do this. How do I acces my inventory? Can I acces my inventory? I cannot acces my inventory, but then how will I know what i've picked up? Dont question this sh*t, just roll with it this game will not explain sh*t to you. Mash your face against all the doors because its a hassle to try and open them and to figure out if you have the right key for this door or not.  I have 3 keys, can I toggle between them? No? So, should I assume that I use all the keys that I have on this one door that I'm currently humping? The door may be partially open, you may smash your weight in full against the door. That thing aint opening till you click and drag its♥♥♥♥♥open. HOLY SH*T WHAT WAS THAT. I am legit scared.. Why are there hands coming out of the floor?!Mini heart attack because my friend killed us all. Start a new lobby, now filled with extra randomers, it's all good. Start game, repeat. Running around the game for a full 20 minutes only to realise that our monster left, or disconnected or maybe more likely, crashed. Find out that you could open cabininets 'n shizzle, did I mention this game doesnt tell you sh*t? Start a new game, choose to be a monster this time. Got to be a Monster for a whole 5 seconds before CRASHHH. Not even 1 hour of play time, 3 crashes...  I'd grade this game a 2/10 would crash again.

content:
Posted: January 11, 2014
Early Access Review
								Do NOT buy this game if you intend to play with friends, you might face unsolvable connection problems. These problems do not matter that much if you play alone with random people.1. We can not connect to each other despite port forwarding and such.2. "Host Time Out" or something. Yes, we googled and browsed the community hub for fixes. lol nope. No solution.3. Game randomly crashes when starting or exiting an ongoing match.After 1.2 hours of troubleshooting, we were not able to fix any of said problems.I played a quick game in a random lobby but got quickly turned off by some weird mouse stuttering. The game felt like its locked at 30 FPS because of this.I can not tell you anything about the gameplay though, because I did not actually play the game yet.I strongly suggest to wait until full release or at least until the beta launches. This game is way too unstable right now.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2014
Early Access Review
								This isnt so much early access as "early early access," or as normal people call it, "scam"There are no explanations to CORE GAME MECHANICS. "You want to know how something works? ♥♥♥♥ you, we arent going to tell," the game says. Speculation speculation speculation, that is what this game seems to go by. Anything pretty much goes in this game, there are no set rules. ♥♥♥♥, it even had an identity crisis upon launch as it said "You have no activated your copy of TERROR yet." Even the lobby is bugged, when the text box appears to be at the middle of the screen, but in reality, you have to type from the bottom left corner, where it looks like it is just empty.I really wanted to love this game, but right now, all I can feel is "meh," borderline "give me a refund"There is early access, then there is throwing out a barebones game and disregarding how rushed and empty it is just by saying "hurr durr, its an alpha." I wouldnt be surprised if they completely stopped development and ran off with this money.I'm still going to play it and try to convince myself it was worth it, while getting in the world's top scientists to determine what the ♥♥♥♥ the rules are in this game, because nobody else can seem to do so

								Game has a good concept, but the monster is overpowered. It's extremely easy for the monster to just sit and wait on the survivors to come and then it's a quick kill. The items you have to hunt are too ambiguious and you spend the majority of the time running from room to room looking for a very small item that is easily missed then running back to EVERY door and safe you have come across to see if it opens the said door. If it does, there's a 75% chance that the door you just opened has nothing of value.Great concept, but the items you have to find need to be made simpler because right now it just goes on forever looking for items and it's way too easy for the monster to find and kill the survivors.

content:
Posted: October 1, 2015
												I never thought I would enjoy a game that treads to close to the "note collector genre" so heavily, but here I am. Damned is  an asymmetric 5-player multiplayer game where one player controls one of three different monsters, each with different abilities and methods of detecting the humans, and the other players play as humans trying to escape by finding keys and tools in the environment to make it through to the exit. The game has 12 maps, giving it a good amount of replayability. The voice chat system was one of my favorite parts of the game, featuring a 3D audio option that makes each player's voice come through their character's position instead of being global, encouraging them to stick together in standard horror movie fashion while also allowing the monster to taunt them.The thing that I like about this game is that unlike other asymmetrical games like Evolve, Damned isn't afraid to kill off players. It treats the humans the same way that any horror movie would, and if they don't stick together and find a way out quickly they aren't going to survive. The keys can be pretty well-hidden, and Damned is the only game where I've ever seen a group of players slowly succumb one by one to the realization that they might not ever find the key they missed somewhere, if the key even existed at all. The tension of new players figuring out what to do and what not to do to avoid alerting the monster while finding their way out is a lot of fun, and while I haven't played past that point to know what it'll be like once I know all the tricks, I think there's enough content to it that I would still enjoy it.The big problem with the game is that it's pretty buggy in its current state, despite no longer being in early access. When I first started playing the game it had capped itself to 15 FPS, and the only way to fix it was to restart my computer. Even after that, the game is generally poorly optimized from what I've seen from other players (I was able to run it at a pretty consistent 80-90 FPS, which isn't really ideal since I have a 144 hz monitor and a computer that should be running it at far past that framerate, but oh well). The other issue is that the game isn't exactly populated. A quick look at the server list showed 7 lobbies, 3 of which were public, and 1 of those had a ping of over 1000. This is the sort of game where you should buy a bundle and play with a group of friends instead of relying on random players, but it's more fun with friends anyways so I didn't mind.In its current state I wouldn't recommend this game at all for $20, but it seems to go on sale in various indie bundles fairly often (I bought a four-pack of the game for like $1 or so at some point or another), and if another four-pack deal comes up and you can get it for cheap it's a great way to spend a few nights with a few friends.

content:
Posted: October 9, 2014
												I wrote a full review that you can read here: http://rgz.ca/gaming/damned-review-stereotypical-horror/tl;dr:I won’t deny that the game had potential. The fact that it is doing something similar to Evolve, one of this year’s major titles, but in more of a survival horror setting and less of an eSports setting shows that. The fact of the matter is that it is poorly designed, slow, isn’t scary, rehashes survival horror concepts that are both lamented and don’t make a lot of sense to begin with, and is unpolished on top of that. It is unpolished to the point that you may be completely unable to play the game for hours on end or give up on trying before you even get to play it at all. I had a hard time getting the other members of the team I played with to stick with it for this review. That should say something about it there. It had potential but it missed its mark by a long shot.

content:
Posted: October 4, 2015
												Damned is a 3D horror co-op multiplayer game.After many normal horror games I have encountered a multiplayer version !!To begin with, you do need a separate account in order to play online. (I hate that)Personally, I would only want to play this game with friends.Playing with unknown people sometimes ruins the horror experience.It is a game where a few sessions are fun.Unfortunately, you run into problems quickly.Game looks pretty good.Control are fine and you get used to it after a short time.Unfortunately, the game has many errors / bugs.And it sometimes ruins the game a little bit.AI does not function properly and that is a shame.Game is already very extensive.Various monsters and some maps, but.... I want more !!!Unfortunately I don't think there is enough considering the normal price.This is not an FPS so no weapons and only a flashlight.Understand also that horror game as it should be and therefore this is not a game for me.The price is very high for this game and I'll hope it will drop in price or get frequent sales.And especially for a 4 pack would be important since this is a multiplayer game so that you immediately can play with your friends.Hope that the makers fix all bugs so the game is a fun experience for everyone.I give it a 7/10 and fairly high because it is quite original concepts is that you do not see much.I think this game can be very good.But I stopped playing after a few hours.I wanted to to shoot some freaking zombies / monsters..... !!Let me at least kick someone their♥♥♥♥♥?? with a flashlight !!!If you liked this review or want to see more recommended games, be sure to follow our curator group: Follow Original Curator Group

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								Incredibly fun. Sort of a multiplayer Amnesia with how the monsters are unstoppable and need to be avoided. Since they're players too, you can even fool them in more interesting ways. Survivor gameplay is a key hunt with randomized key locations, in which you slowly unlock your way through the stage, which usually ends up being a sprawling complex. The game manages to make you want to stick together and split up at the same time, as staying with your friends means the monster can kill all of you at once possibly, while splitting up means you get insanity effects such as losing your light almost entirely or hands reaching from the floor to slow you down. The game is very intense as the last survivor alive, and you feel like you earned it if you make it out.As the monster, gameplay is also tons of fun. There are three different monsters you can be: Lurker, who needs to set traps so he can hear where the players are, and then switch into his physical form which can actually see them to kill them, the Phantom which can't see much and needs to listen for the player's footsteps to figure out where they are. Finally, there's Mary, who is a spooky lady like the usual stringy-haired cliche is, and she moves very slowly, but drains power if she gets near to the players, and when she's full she can go crazy and start tearing up everything at lightning speed. Traps work against her, since she activates them by being nearby, thus alerting the players, and she will randomly teleport after not teleporting for too long, which can save a survivor from being killed. On the other hand, she can also teleport herself at will every minute or so which can help her get around.Honestly, this game is very fun, and I recommend it. Even playing with random people in public games can be fun, thanks to the way the game works.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 31, 2014
Early Access Review
								Damned is awesome.  Simply put, it's hide-and-seek with five people, one being the monster.  The survivors hunt for keys, and the monster tries to kill them before they can escape.  As of this review, there are two monsters with very different playstyles: a ghost that tracks by sound alone and a skinless horror that switches between two dimensions, only one of which it can kill you in.  As the game is still in alpha, updates are constantly being made, and many more maps, survivors, and monsters are sure to come in the future.  I'll update this when the game is actually released, but it's still definitely worth buying now. The devs are actually open to input from the players, and the alpha itself is very playable (though not without some bugs/inconveniences).  Anyway, I write this so more people will play it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								Damned is a really fun Survival Horror game where both the survivors and the monster are players. The (maximum of 4) Survivors run around the map rushing to find the different keys/codes to open doors/safes whilst trying to avoid the Monster, who is trying to kill them (there are only 2 types of monster at the time of this review). This can lead to some pretty tense moments of blubbering in a corner whilst the monster metaphorically sniffs around trying to find you. The surprising thing about Damned is that even though it's in alpha, it's still a really good game! Yes, they have bugs to fix, but lately they have really gotten around to fixing a good majority of them.At the time of this "review", the game has a relatively small playerbase outside of the swarm of players every major update. If you're going to buy this game, the best way to do enjoy it would be to buy it alongside your friends, or to get the multi-copy pack so nobody gets left out.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 5, 2013
Early Access Review
								Damned, though currently in Alpha, is shaping to be a great multiplayer horror game. I'm surprised by the amount of scares this game has given me. No other game have I found myself screaming like a schoolgirl while running away from a monster. Think of this game as an online hide and go seek. Players must try and escape a house with 3 other players while a 5th player plays as either a Phantom or Lurker. The Phantom/Lurker player can instantly kill other players if they sucessfully find them. However, they are limited by their visionary differences and will have to set traps and listen to sounds to find the players. For example, players are invisible to the monsters unless they trigger sequences that will allow them to hunt these players down.The players must find keys, safe codes, and items that will help them open doors and advance to next rooms. The game is randomized so every level will have their items placed in random drawers and rooms so there is replay value.Ideally the the real fun is a monster player who paces themselves and does not instantly kill all players if given the opportunity. I prefer to scare players and leave them alive just as they think I'm about to kill them. I hear their screams and that alone gives a different kind of thrill I've never experienced in any other game. This game is more fun if players focus more about the experience instead of the objective.Best of all, check out the forum. The developers have been listening to fan feedback and have tweaked and altered the game accordingly.Try it out, there's a lot of potential, and be sure to talk to your teammates. Most of the fun is based on the interaction with the other players.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
Early Access Review
								Ho man, do I love this game.  At the time of writing this review, the game is still in alpha.  That being said, for a game at this stage of development, it's a solid game.  The concept is original and the execution is already good and still morphing into something even better as the developers receive feedback.  It's fund being both the humans and the monster, though between the two currently available (lurker and phantom) the lurker is definitely the favoured one.  The challenge exists for both the humans and the monster since the humans always have that feeling of dread that the monster is around every corner and struggling to advance while the monster is actually on the other side of the map desparately trying to claw his way out of a closet trying to find the last survivor.  I would say it's a definite winner with a good amount of replayability either with friends or online with strangers,

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
Early Access Review
								What the developers have designed here is a Slender type game where you scamper through a house/hotel/asylum looking for a way to escape. The caveat here is that one person plays the monster. It's brilliant and novel.  As an Alpha it is very playable, though there are some balancing issues as they continue to develop.  There are currently two monster's available the original Lurker  and the phantom.  I have found that the Lurker still is the more enjoyable of the two, as the Phantom doesn't seem to be balanced yet. Either it's too weak or too powerful.  Hopefully sometime in the future they'll get it right.  If you have the friends to play it, and can stomach the growing pains of a developing game, I highly recommend it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
Early Access Review
								This CO-OP survival game is shaping up to become something that I've been longing for on any platform. Up to four players trying to survive certain doom in different maps and searching for keys with only a flashlight in hand can be really intense. Especially when you know the enemy (a player-controlled monster that can go from invisible to visible in the blink of an eye) is lurking around every corner. Might even be walking right behind without you knowing it. This is a game that needs the players to cooperate to survive. As a monster your sole purpose is to make sure the humans won't get away. Afterall they're yours to feast upon. The game is still in alpha and needs more work and polish. There are not many maps or monsters but they're coming. The developers are hard at work and I've seen this game change since I first bought it. Even though it's still in alpha this game delivers plenty of fun, especially for LAN with friends. While playing with random people can be fun this game really delivers when playing with people you know. This is where Damned really shines! If you, like me, is longing for a cooperative, atmospheric horror title which is not centered around shooting things this might be for you! If your tired of being able to kill everything in your path, no matter how great the danger, and want something that can keep you on the edge of your seat, delivering a different experience every time this is for you. If you enjoy being able to rip every other player apart this is also for you! I'm really enjoying this game and I'm looking forward to see it evolve into a finished product.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
Early Access Review
								A nice game for friends. Though still in alpha at the time of this review, this game seems to have overtaken the amount of time I've put into other games on my list. Its potential, as well as its ability to scare with a human directing the actions of the antagonist really make this an enjoyable game to be play-testing. More content's to be added, and while the competitive portion of the game is lacking with some obvious issues, the spirit of the game is clear; many of those problems apart from the wonderful wealth of bugs are solved by playing within that spirit, which is to have a great time scaring the hell out of your friends. The premise of the game is simple. One player plays a monster, or Haunt rather, and attempts to hunt down and scare the hell out of four survivors trapped within the location. The survivors' goal is to get the requisite items they need to escape, whether that be keys, codes to open safes, crowbars, or hammers. It's an interesting experience, and the fear of the monster is compounded by the lack of weaponry on the part of the survivors. Anyone who's played Amnesia will appreciate the blessing and curse of the control scheme and the helplessness of the survivors who are forced to either run or hide. I reccommend this to anyone willing to lay down the measly asking price to give it a chance and live within the spirit of Haunted House on the Hill and the B-movie slashers.

content:

Early Access Review
								Damned is awesome.  Simply put, it's hide-and-seek with five people, one being the monster.  The survivors hunt for keys, and the monster tries to kill them before they can escape.  As of this review, there are two monsters with very different playstyles: a ghost that tracks by sound alone and a skinless horror that switches between two dimensions, only one of which it can kill you in.  As the game is still in alpha, updates are constantly being made, and many more maps, survivors, and monsters are sure to come in the future.  I'll update this when the game is actually released, but it's still definitely worth buying now. The devs are actually open to input from the players, and the alpha itself is very playable (though not without some bugs/inconveniences).  Anyway, I write this so more people will play it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
Early Access Review
								This CO-OP survival game is shaping up to become something that I've been longing for on any platform. Up to four players trying to survive certain doom in different maps and searching for keys with only a flashlight in hand can be really intense. Especially when you know the enemy (a player-controlled monster that can go from invisible to visible in the blink of an eye) is lurking around every corner. Might even be walking right behind without you knowing it. This is a game that needs the players to cooperate to survive. As a monster your sole purpose is to make sure the humans won't get away. Afterall they're yours to feast upon. The game is still in alpha and needs more work and polish. There are not many maps or monsters but they're coming. The developers are hard at work and I've seen this game change since I first bought it. Even though it's still in alpha this game delivers plenty of fun, especially for LAN with friends. While playing with random people can be fun this game really delivers when playing with people you know. This is where Damned really shines! If you, like me, is longing for a cooperative, atmospheric horror title which is not centered around shooting things this might be for you! If your tired of being able to kill everything in your path, no matter how great the danger, and want something that can keep you on the edge of your seat, delivering a different experience every time this is for you. If you enjoy being able to rip every other player apart this is also for you! I'm really enjoying this game and I'm looking forward to see it evolve into a finished product.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 14, 2014
												FNaFYou have met your match.10/102spookySoiled pantsEDIT: FNAF is♥♥♥♥♥♥so it's not really a big surprise why this is better than it.|SERIOUS REVIEW|Damned is a multiplayer survival horror game based around finding keys that are swapped and moved around before each match. As such, the game relies heavily on of quick thinking and teamwork to cover as much ground as possible whilst also avoiding one of three monsters: The Lurker, The Phantom, and Mary. All three have different advantages and disadvantages.PROS+Game is fun and stays interesting+Controls are intuitive and easy to get used to+Maps are balanced to allow either the monster or survivors to win+Actually spookyCONS-Game runs strangly, even on high-end machines-Requires a free, seperate account created in-game to play-Eventually becomes stagnant and boring if you end up playing for too long-Outdated visuals and average audio componentsOVERALLAudio-7/10Gameplay-8/10Visuals-7/10Multiplayer-9/10Overall, Damned is a fun and fairly cheap horror game made for a few fun nights with friends or strangers. The game changes itself enough to avoid boredom after one or two games, but eventually you will want to take a break from the game after your 5th match of the night. The audio and the visuals are unassuming, neither terrible nor great, and the strange performance lapses make the game far from perfect.Final Grade-7/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												Damned has the potential to be a good game, but it isn't. Atleast in it's current state. The game still has some annoying bugs. Whenever someone hosts a game, they choose when to start the game. If the host starts the game before everyone has loaded in, the game crashes for whoever has not loaded in yet and their character instantly dies. It took us a little while to figure out why this was happening, but once we figured it out the bug was easy to avoid. Also, I noticed the game tends to crash if you choose to play multiple rounds within the same lobby. Aside from all the bugs, the gameplay isn't anything to write home about. The monsters/ghosts kill the survivors really easily, but the monsters can choose to drag the match out and attempt to scare the survivors before slaughtering them. In most of the public matches I've played, the monsters just straight up kill you within the first few minutes of the match. They don't attempt to scare you whatsoever, which makes for some lackluster gameplay. If you somehow make it past the ten minute mark, your character starts to have a psychotic break. The longer you go without beating the game(escaping), or getting killed, the symptoms intensify. For instance, hands start to come out the floor which prevent the player from moving. I won't spoil anymore of the symptoms for those who choose to buy the game. One weird thing about the whole psychotic break thing is that all the symptoms are completely clientside, meaning your teammates can't see any of the symptoms you are currently experiencing. I guess this is because it's all in your head, right?If you choose to buy this game, I suggest you play it with a group of friends. If you don't have a group of friends to play with, then don't bother with this game.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
												First, let me state that I was following this game since Early Access, but waited for "Full Release."  I was exceedingly hopeful for this game.The reasons I CANNOT recommend this game are the following:It is horribly incomplete and one-dimensional.There is but one thing to do in the game: Run like a moron and hope you don't miss a vital key in a bucket or some crevice while the already-lethal ghost is chasing you down, clicking their mouse button til you get close enough for the kill shot to register.There is no depth to this game in regards to gameplay.  There are no complex objectives requiring any kind of cooperation among the players.  The monster/ghost role is as simple as just left clicking and holding down W.This game has so much potential, but I fear the developers aren't able to provide anything more than a short-lived atmospheric bore-fest.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
												Well, the creep factor is there. And the idea for the gameplay is kind of unique. The graphics need some work, for example some of the monster trap/ visual effects were a little too corporeal or cheesy. Being the monster is super fun, but a little frustrating at times. The scary sounds and general audio stuff if really cool. I would recommend that the developer add some more variety and add some bass/ super low sounds. Bass and sub-bass have been used to build horror tension for years in film. This game could benefit from that.Overall, I'm good with this as at $10 or less, much more than that isn't really worth. The reason for this is that the graphics are dated, the gameplay mechanics need tweaking, and the game likes to crash :/About the crashing... I've played 4 matches, but  have suffered 2 crashes requiring task manager to end task/quit. One match ended with the player characters (using a 3rd party voice chat) straight up telling the monster player where to find them, as the map seemed glitched... 4 players spent 30 minutes and only could find batteries.  We suspected that the map glitched or that items didn't spawn. The maps are really awesome and typical horror locale tropes. I'm loving the maps. What I don't love is that the searching for items gets a little boring if you've stayed clear of danger. I mean like 20+ minutes of wondering around. I had like 8 keys one time and had no clue what to do. As the monster, you spend a lot of time just wondering around... "where... what... arg"- moving too slowly in these gargantuan maps and feeling like you can't really get anything done. I feel like the monsters need more keyboard interaction, like some extra abilities to mess with people. Mary could use something for sure, like maybe the ability to make the walls bleed or turn invisible for a few seconds. The Lurker really needs a way to keep track of traps and triggers. As for the Phantom, the character model is horribly cheesy. It looks like a ghost of of an old n64 game or something. As I've not tried Phantom yet, I can't say what could improve game for it.If this game gets some crash fix and some gameplay tweaks, then I would highly recommend it. Until then, meh. Grab it if it's cheap, at least to try it and support the developer.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
												\\\\Down below is my review from 24 december 2014//////I can't recommend this game at its current state, even though I really want because it has so much potential! Here are some major flaws that needs to be fixed:1. 20$ price tag and claimed to be a release? This game is very buggy and the worst part is that it's most game breaking bugs, so get used to alot of crashes. 5/10 lobbies I create end up crashing for all other players than the host, so everyone disconnects and I have to start all over (crashes confirmed by friend). This game should be marked for early access because it is not finished in any way. I bought this for 1/4 the price, at that cost I can handle it. But buying this for 20 euros is a rip-off.2. Strategies. If you play this game with 4 friends over skype, you'll be fine. But if you play it with any amount of friends or any other players and talk in game you won't be fine. The fatal flaw is that the ghost can hear you talking. May I ask why? Ghost can't see you write in the chat, but it can hear you talk so it defeats the whole purpose of talking in game. And writiting out strategies is not as useful when you have Mary running amok behind you.3. Pretty unbalanced and dull rooms. This game is really hard as survivor, I completed this once when the ghost was AFK and it took around 20 minutes. I can just imagine doing all that key searching while there's a ghost active aswell, gotta take atleast twice the time. Playing this with random people is almost impossible, especially since the ghost can hear you. There is one room at one map were there are about 20 wardrobes shaped as a mace. What's the fun of looking through 20 wardrobes? One a final note, this game could become something huge. This game could very well be worth 20 euros in the future, because the dev keeps pushing out updates now and then, which is very nice. But I can't recommend this at current state. It's is not a full release.^^^^Above is my Review from 24 december 2014^^^^^I am now changing my review to recommending. Since I started to play this game a week ago (This is written 11 June 2015) I've had no problem with crashing and lobbies that don't work. They've also added so that you can join in game session even if they are running, making the spectating a bit shorter. Game still has the same price tag and the monster will still hear you. But atleast the game works now, so that's why I am changing this review.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2014
												Creepy.  CREEEEEEPY.  While playing as each of the monster types really takes getting used to, it is most gratifying when you succeed in your objective.  The only real down side(s) to the game are playing as the survivours, such as when you're the first one in the party to be killed by the monster, and one or more of your team-mates succeeds in evading the monster for a much longer period of time.  You spend a lot of time in spectator mode when that happens.  They can also be at a disadvantage (aside from dying on one hit) when the insanity effects crop up and leave you either slowed down or unable to move, but given the monster weaknesses, I think that can be worked through with practice.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 19, 2014
												The game is Ok... New players would definetly get a few scares here and there as they get used to the random things that occurs, mostly jump scares, but after an hour or so the fear glamour is gone. And that's when the flaws are more inherently noticeable. In this game survivors are suppose to interact with items in order to find keys to progress further and escape, however for new comers, those highlighted interactive objects are almost unnoticeable even if the player is right smack infront of it. So unless the player already spend alot of time playing the game or seen a video/read a guide of some sort prior they would most definitely miss it. Sad to say half the games I'm in  players eventually gave up the hunt and dc after 10 or so min being stuck. At least the monsters are flushed up somewhat better with a more unique style of play. There's a bit of a learning curve, mainly b/c there's hardly any notifiers or a tutorial of sorts to explain what to do or E is the transform for monsters, but the players should be able to grasp it as they're somewhat simplistic. The bottom line is this game is at a beta stage, there are still lots of  bugs here and there (take a look at forum lots of people can't play lan with same IP, can't even load the game despite an old engine, and random item clipping/crash galore), and needs alot more tweaking to call it a game in it's final stages. Not worth the full price , but if you can get it on sale, I did, $5 sounds is just about right for this unpolished game.

The game has come a long way featuring two new monsters, and a few new levels. New effects like film grain, and depth fog help the atmosphere of the game. I would recommend this game to anyone who is into this genre. People will talk about the atmosphere being ruined once you discover the patterns and tactics of the monsters. I have accumulated almost 50 hours and I still can get scared and want to run from a monster. Overall 8/10. Solid game with slight bugs. I would recommend buying on sale if you do not thoroughly enjoy this genre.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 31, 2015
												There are now several horror games where you find yourself alone in some building with a monster that wants to nibble your giblets. So why not make it a multiplayer experience where a group of a maximum 4 players need to escape that same building, but with a player being the monster? That's Damned for you.Damned is a First Person Multiplayer Survival Horror in its early phase. While at a first glance it might not look more interesting than Amnesia or Slender, I can assure you, being against a human monster is completely different. The dev team thought of almost everything in this game so far. With multiple usable types of monsters, randomized item layout, appreciable graphics for an early game and terrifying sounds and soundtracks, this game manages to stay fresh even after several matches. The amount of situations that could occur is enormous.There still are some bugs to be worked upon, like a certain instability on most computers and some problems with randomization that will rarely make a map "unbeatable" from the Survivors' point of view, and the monsters are currently a bit overpowered.However, the Survivors can beat the monster, oh yes. How? Teamwork, communication. This game forces the humans to communicate, even though they could be heard and detected by the monster. The game won't take you by the hand, there's no tutorial to be learned.All you'll know about this game will come from guides and experience.If you like horror games with exploration features, it's completely worth a try, especially if you have up to 4 friends to play with.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 10, 2016
												TLDR: Great co-op atmospheric horror game.  Play with friends. Pick it up on sale.  In a lot of ways Damned is a little bit of a hot mess.  Past versions have been buggy to a sometimes unplayable degree (We've had required keys and items not spawn on maps, in the most recent version of the game this hasn't happened.)  But as it stands, Damned is easily the best co-op horror game on Steam, and I think it will probably stay this way for awhile.What Damned gets rights is the atmosphere.  Most of the levels are genuinely creepy, especially when the longer you play on the levels, the hallucinations such as hands rising from the floor and slowing you down, flashlights flickering, your screen going black and so on become more and more frequent.  There ends up being a real sense of danger the longer you play.When the game really shines though is when the player that's the Monster doesn't just go into it to win, but rather they attempt to create an experience for the players as well.  Ocasionally Mary will get a lucky teleport and end up right in front of, or behind the group.  They don't instantly go beserk and kill the players, they'll just stand or follow them, then go beserk or teleport away once they're seen.  It adds to much to the experience for the monster to toy with the survivors as opposed to just kill them and end the round as quickly as possible.  Even better to pick them off one by one.I have a really hard time reccomending Damned at full price, but when it's on sale it's absolutely worth a pick up.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 6, 2015
												This game has a really amazing concept to it. It has great horror factors to it, hardly relying on jumpscares as its main focus of fright. It also has unique types of Monsters you can play as; the Lurker (completly blind, but can set audio traps to pin-point where survivers went and manifest into a solid being), the Phantom (another blind Monster, but you can see surivers hinding behind walls or objects once you first see them) and Mary (a spectral girl similar to the Grudge spirit that is always visible, walks very slowly, but has a frenzy attack if she focuses on a surviver for a certain amount of time). Alas, this game is still ridden with terrible flaws that make it hard for me to recommened this game to anyone.FIrst off, they made the mosters waaaaaaaaaaaay overpowered.  They can kill you in one hit and there's no life meter for the survivers. You can set how many lifes you have, but they're shared with the other survivers. Secondly, the survivers have absolutly no way to defend themselves. All you have equiped is your flashlight and whatever you find while scowering whatever place you spawn in (keys, hammers, and crowbars). There are no weapons for you to get to defend yourself from the Monsters. Thirdly, respawing is broken. There's been a few times while playing this game with some of my friends that one of them respawned right next to the Monster. Lastly, there's hidden effects that happen to you, while some are accecptible, others are not. One I think is okay is where your character will start halucenating if your flashlight's battery is low. The other is how stamina is both there and it's not. Sometimes you can run just fine, but then you halt to a walk and can only sometimes run. There's also no meter for your stamina.If this game could get some fixes, I would recommend this game. As it is right now, I just can't justify it as a good game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 5, 2015
												This is a horrible tease. I see what it wants to be and it's so close to being so scary you can taste it. But it falls short.The Beauty:The concept is one of the strongest things this game has going for it. Multiplayer survival horror is great by itself, but add in that one of your irl friends is working against you as this terrifying thing trying to kill you? 5/5 stars. It's working both sides of haunted houses: actors and patrons. The monster usually has something that makes it distinct as a terror which adds to the goosebumps. This game does deliver scares.The Ugly:The survivors' confusion doesn't clear up as they explore. I have played as survivors and monsters on every map. I have yet to see survivors win. Ever. Or make any remarkable progress for that matter. Sure, sometimes you get a key that unlocks a chain or door and now you can move around a little more in this new area, but chances are it still doesn't help you get anywhere. I've played passively as the monster just to see if it was possible for survivors to win. I used the monster to scout out maps to help a little. My team gave up. It's too one-sided. Monster can win easily enough (I wouldn't change much to balance that), but survivors just can't win (I would change this significantly). Monster controls are also bizarre. Lurker is most logical, but the other two could use some instructions so the powerful monster actually feels powerful. There should be no confusion there. Throw in a few glitches and it isn't playable.

Posted: February 10, 2015
												I love the style of the game. It's horror meets escape-the-room; two of my favorite types. It's a bit like Amnesia, only you play as either the monster (one of 3 choices) trying to kill everyone, or one of four "survivors" trying to escape the place you're trapped in by collecting keys to unlock doors. A few problems with game bugs - getting stuck in walls, game disconnecting, dying sometimes produces two dead bodies or a live body running into a wall, but otherwise the game is playable and worth the $20 if they fix the bugs. Best played with a group of friends, in a dark room, with voice chat. Really adds to the creepiness, or hilarity (if you have friends like mine).

												I would not reccomend this to anyone. It's a laagy nightmare (despite using virtually no resources) even just trying to navigate the menu. It's virtually unplayable for the same reason. I've seen better games on steam for WAY less money, and I'm rather shocked that something like this that barely runs is going for as much as it is. I had it gifted to me and I would still return it for refund if I could... I lack words to adequately describe the frustration the mere attempt of getting into the game, and then trying to move (only to find that it was just as bad as the launch screen) caused. Interesting premise or not, the core aspect integral to a game's success is its playability, and if it is unplayable, then it has failed at the most important objective.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 8, 2015
												Bought this game during a recent sale and tried to make it work for 3 other friends. I really wanted to like this game.The concept of 4 survivors vs. 1 monster on a server game was very appealing to me, and for $5 a person (during the sale) how could I really say no? The atmosphere is creepy, the sound is great, and once you understand the controls it plays well. Sure the elements get reused so you can't tell a level apart from another level and THE FOREST just crashes the game, but it's not that bad design-wise.The direction in this game is lacking, playing as a survivor is confusing and difficult. Winning as a survivor requires finding a silver key and a crowbar/hammer and having all living survivors in the escape room for 10 seconds. Finding a key can unlock a door that does nothing or unlocks multiple doors and in almost 3 hours of playing we found 1 hammer out of 5 maps as survivors. It's frustrating walking around for 4 or 5 minutes and not being able to go anywhere if you don't find the right key in the right order.Playing as a monster has its drawbacks depending on the monster, but it's still the most fun part of the game. The 'phantom' appears to play the easiest when it comes to finding survivors that aren't careful, the 'lurker' is the most terrifying but require the most guesswork when turning on/off corporeal form and 'mary' is irritating when she isn't charged and moves as slow as she does, but teleporting can land you in the best position or set you back at the worst time.Also creating a profile and setting up a room/finding one can be annoying, but it's not Uplay... so there's that.TLDR: Great look and feel, confusing and unbalanced gameplay2/5 - Not Worth $5

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
Early Access Review
								Mary needs a lot of improvements. Me and my friends were so hyped to play and it turned into a game of actually trying to FIND the monster. She teleports like every 20 seconds automatically no matter what the circumstance. Every time me or my friend were the monster we would finally find a survivor and then boom, we would teleport a mile away again so we get to walk 1 mph across the map all over again. Not to mention you have to look at her for about 6 seconds before she can charge you which I doubt people will do. Here's my opinion on what should be changed:-You aren't forced to randomly teleport and you can do so on your own will-Mary can charge you as soon as your crosshair goes over here therefor actually making it a challenge and not just strolling away-Make it so you can't teleport into locked rooms. Once a room is unlocked than it becomes part of the random teleport options. I spawned in a locked room and had to wait for the charge about 85% of the game.-Her slow walkspeed makes her more creepy so as long as she can charge you better than I don't think that should be changed as long as you don't have to stroll across the map for an hour.I love the maps and Mary seems to be the only true horrifying monster so we really wanna do a game with her without these problems. Otherwise this game has a good concept and is really fun to play with friends.

content:
Posted: November 14, 2014
												I've played this game for many hours with my friends and it has been amazing. However, I feel that by playing with my friends we've made the most out of it ourselves, rather than the game doing most of the talking for us. And if I didn't have anybody to play this with I do think the game would be left gathering dust in my steam library. But this being said I believe the game is aimed towards friends playing it together ( Unless you want to scare the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of people being the monster).The diversity between the maps, spawn locations are completely unique which does contribute towards the "never playing the same scenario twice" theme which is always a bonus. In addition, a lot of the maps are just rearrangements of each other. I want a few more options to chose from, how about a map thats half outside? Or a map based in an abadoned school/circus? I don't know if there is currently new maps under construction as it still is in early development, but im slowly growing tired of the rehash of a large amount of the maps.Also I would like more monster variation, the currently ones are good but once you suss out how to beat them it loses its scare factor in a way. And some of the character grab and pull/push mechanics are a littly bit flunky and robotic at times, but they're nothing major to worry about because im sure they'll soon get sorted.Don't get me wrong im not critising the game because I really enjoy playing it, I just want it even better. It was definitely well worth the money.If you want to watch videos on the game my friend recorded us playing - https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCZYMt8Etov6DyoudwQF5_hA

												Very unique idea and excellent game. If you enjoy getting scared and scaring people then this is the game for you. There is a max of 5 players per game. Four play as survivors trapped in a hotel, asylum, etc. The other person plays as one of three monsters. The survivors goal is to find keys and other object to escape, while trying to avoid getting killed by the monster. Of course the monsters goal is to kill all the players. Definitely worth the money!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 19, 2014
												Picked this up yesterday (18/12/14) in the Winter Sales and a few other copies for friends. Wasn't really expecting a great deal from it but I was pleasently surprised. It's a fairly simple game but that's not to say it isn't fun and attention-grabbing. Having a full lobby (5 Players = 4 Humans + 1 Monster) made for a really tense atmosphere as one by one we were picked off by the monster and grew more and more ready to brown our trousers. I Haven't exactly played a lot (1 session) so this is more of a first impression. I may add to this review as I play and discover more. For now I shall leave a few Pros & Cons: PROS:- Simple yet fun- Immesive/ atmospheric music, scenery, sounds and lighting.- A nice (albeit small) veriety of Monster's abilities, they aren't just different skins- Decent graphics (helps with immersion, for me)CONS:- The lobbies can be somewhat buggy, people not appearing/ unable to see other players- No explaination on how to use Inventory items (a little note in controls or a tool tip would be grand)- No way (that I can see) to tell when your Monster's Transformation skill is ready (a little HUD bar?)- Flashlight battery seems to drain even when left off (creeping in the dark with it off and it suddenly flickers)SUMMARY:A really fun game to burn some time with friends. A good deal of tension and atmosphere along with the screams of your mates makes for some scary good tiimes. Seeing as this is on sale I recommend you grab a 4-Pack and dish these out to some pals ASAP.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 12, 2014
												FIRST VIEW (12th of June)   To be honest, I'm not sure if it's possible to write a helpful review for an Early Access Game.But I'll do my best.   I played this game while it was on Alpha and while it was on Beta and here's what I can say. Now there are a bunch sad things in "Damned". It lags, freezes, crashes and stuff. There are just a couple of servers, so it's almost dead online. Also there are several bugs like doors getting stuck and items which can't be picked up.   So that really can disappoint a player.But on the other hand "Damned" has good original concept. When I managed to play a couple of rounds it was pretty fun and scary. The atmosphere itself is creepy, but people's reactions, commentary are making gaming process pretty fun.I bet when you play with your friends it's even funnier.   So is it good or bad? I don't know. But I hope that developers will fix all the troubles which players have right now. And if they do so I'm pretty sure the answer will be obvious. :)--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------                                                          UPDATE (24th of July)   Well now we're talking! Developers updated game pretty well and I'm really happy about it! :)So the reason I checked the game again was patch which added achievements and trading cards. Which is pretty cool I think. Makes gaming process little more interesting. But when I played the game itself, like for real, I was surprised.    "Damned" became even more scary that it was! And by "scary" I mean horrifying! Now you can get scared even without a monster. The atmosphere of the game is way more creepier: developers added some jumpscares, some spooky events and other stuff.   Another good thing: more people play this game now. So you actually can play this game even if your friends don't.   The amount of bugs is reduced, but there are still few of them. At least it's obvious that developers DO work and they DO try to fix them.    Looking forward for other updates. Good luck to developers. Now I can recommend this game with even more passion!--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------                                                          UPDATE (19th of December)   Haven't been able to play this game for like 4 months. Just can't lauch the game.Well, what can you do about it.

content:
Posted: December 1, 2014
												After reading some of the reviews I was a bit skeptical, but this game is fun. While there is not an abundance of maps or monsters the game does not feel repedative at all. This game will have you tense and give you a bigger heart attack than a chicken at a poultry processing factory. I would reccomend informing yourself about the basic monsters before you play as each is very different  and knowing how to play each one can save your life. The one thing I dislike is that is buggy, but otherwise a great deal when on sale. You will get at the bare minimum 10 hours of fun from this game. I would love to see it expanded with more map, more monsters, easier door mechanics, and possibly having the survivors have different strengths (EX: mia can run 10% faster or father jacob sees objects highlight from 10 feet further). The sound track could be higher quality as well.Great game overal given that i paid about five bucks for it, one of my most cost effective games. 7.5/10

I'm no slouch when it comes to computers and networking, and everything is configured properly.I have a very high end gaming PC, and even the menus slow to a crippling 5 fps or less. I've asked for help from the devs on the forum, and have not been helped at all. This game is completely broken, and I only found out after buying a 4 pack. Games like this are a prime reason why Steam needs to offer refunds for broken products. I will definitely be demanding a refund on this one.This doesn't even deserver to be on early access. This isn't even alpha quality. This is junk that doesn't work at all.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 4, 2015
												OH THE HORRORS OF SEARCHING FOR KEYS!!  So many keys, so little time.  It's true, there has been a trend in multiplayer horror games lately, namely rogue-likes, that force you to quest for keys. Here's an example, namely of Damned, but for this kind of game in general:>> KEY1 - Unlocks DOOR1>> DOOR1 - leads to KEY2>> KEY2 - Unlocks DOOR2>> DOOR2 - leads to.....wait, no friggin' key, are you serious?!Backtrack a little, oh there's a key you overlooked.  It unlocks a drawer back in the room DOOR1 leads to, thereby       giving you KEY3.>> KEY3 - Get a crowbar.... : /   and where the sh*t am I supposed to use that?! (HINT: when you finally find KEY10 which will ultimately lead you to a special SILVER KEY, then you'll find the boards you're supposed to pry off with said crowbar)All this fetch quest madness leads to a greater sense of fear and unease in the player.  I have to admit, I found that gameplay mechanic annoying and overly tedious at first.  Since then, it's grown on me.  I realize now that if I were in this situation, with 3 strangers (other Steam players) being stalked by 1 of 3 types of monster (another Steam player; that's right: 4 'survivors' and 1 monster make up the basis of the game 'FIND STUFF TO USE ON THINGS AND AVOID GETTING KILLED BY A 'THING' ALONG THE WAY') that I couldn't possibly know where the keys were to get out of wherever it is that we're all trapped in.  So I guess you could say the fetch quest just makes the situation more realistic. All in all, Damned is a pretty fun game and there are trading cards and achievements too. Don't worry, the achievement for successfully completing a certain number of maps goes both ways - you can do so as the monster (so much fun!!) or as a survivor.  Also, the person that plays as the monster doesn't have the advantage you'd think he/she would have.  The monsters have their own strengths and weaknesses, such as the ghoul not being able to see anyone until it's right on top of them + plus it floats around very slowly.  Mary walks slow, but she can teleport too (but even then that's only so many times until the ability has to recharge, in a manner of speaking - you get more charge/uses the more times that you see survivors) and can only go into a 'frenzy' which allows you to take them down by keeping them in your sight long enough to allow it to activate. The 3rd monster can set traps that allow it to pinpoint where survivors are, as it can't see them until it can go into a stalker/kill mode, which of course you have to wait for between each use of said mode.So Damned is pretty balanced as far as this kind of game goes and will offer far more hours of gameplay than alot of other indie/horror games.  Even more fun if you play with friends (which I haven't done personally, but I think it would be fun).

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 24, 2015
												This one of the very few reviews I've written. I am annoyed enough to actually write one.A number of my friends and I acquired this game through a recent Humble Bundle, expecting a few hours' fun with what reads like a really nice idea for an asymmetric multiplayer game. What we got was a bug ridden, slowly performing, confusing mess across multiple different systems. Let me explain.The game has many problems, most obviously bugs: menus appearing unexpectedly and staying there throughout gameplay; unexpected freezing which forces a quit to menu or process kill; bizarre drops in mouse sensitivity or input tracking; variable framerates; disconnects from multiplayer games yet remaining in the player list; minimal feedback on player/monster actions; the list goes on. We were playing on a mixture of systems, some with NVidia cards and some with AMD, all using Windows 7, and I can say now that we've not had anywhere near as many problems with any other game. The next bunch of issues relate to the game design itself. The basic elements of the gameplay are there, but they seem to be at the level found in a lot of early version mods available for other games. Playing as any of the monsters is actually very shallow in terms of gameplay, and playing as the survivors doesn't really feel like anything beyond semi-coordinated trial and error. There's barely any interaction with levels beyond picking items up and opening doors, the latter of which has a needlessly awkward grab mechanic that in practice doesn't justify its existence. The items are difficult to spot as well, which results in the survivor's role rapidly becoming one of frustration and confusion, especially when playing a new level. As a group Damned sounded fun, and we play in a LAN environment so we hoped the horror aspect would make it a good investment. As it turns out the gameplay is barely fleshed out, and when the game does run it either runs very badly or encounters problems. I just can't recommend it, not with many other games offering much better for a lot less than the Steam price at the time of writing (£15).The worst bit? We experienced all the above in an hour. A single hour. It literally took 60 minutes to exhaust patience of five PC gamers who are happy to mod, tweak, upate drivers, and customise controls, in order to get something working. Did we give it enough time? You decide; we found something else to play.

												First off, let me say that this game has a GREAT premise. The whole idea is genius. But there are just way to many issues with it right now to make it even enjoyable to play. Me and a buddy bought a 4 pack for a cheap date night's with our spouses, and after nearly an hour of frustration we couldnt take it any more. Though I really hope that after a while, and new patches come out, that they can perfect what they are going for.Way too many Glitches. WAY WAY WAY to many glitches. I understand that this is under development, but to let people buy a game that is this sketch with as many bugs and bad quirks and lag issues as it has, if I was the developer I would be personally embarrassed that I am chargeing $20 bucks a pop for a fundimentally broken game, that even for a beta game is bad.If the developers read this, these are the few things that would make it better.1. I shouldnt have to hold down the action button and then move or drag my mouse to open things. Just make a click do that. Even if you have to hold down the button to open in slowly (so you can peek out or whatever) That was just really annoying to constantly be moving my mouse or my position to open a door or a drawer or closet. this was a major problem especially when you take into account the next problem of FPS.2. Frame Rate issues all around. I have a amazing laptop that I built for gaming. The thing is a beast and can handle the newest games, such as farcry 4 for example, at max settings. This game, had issues like crazy, jerky, even on the lowest settings. especially on the main screen. The mouse had lag like nuts, and it took me five mineutes to even change the settings. Eventually, almost like a buffer on the internet, the game got smoother.I really hope that they fix some of the problems with this here in the next year. Because I could see that there was great potential in this game. Something that has never been done before, and it did give us a few screams even with the issues it had. So for the time being, I am going to have to say NO on the recommend this game until it gets further into developement. Once that happens, I would totally recommend this game.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
												I've played this game on and off since the alpha stages. I've had some good times. It can be an excellent source of amusement for you and some friends at the right times. But the problems that plagued it during the alpha stages are still there in its present state, and I just cannot in good faith recommend it to anyone, especially not for the price it has. Among other things, it suffers from a few serious bugs - the most prevalent of these is that you cannot change between fullscreen or windowed mode without the game suffering a complete crash, or even crashing your entire computer. There are connection errors, there are times when you get stuck moving (or being unable to move), times when the menu overlay will stay on your screen forever...the list goes on.It is also sometimes far too dark, which could work with being an atmospheric experience, but when you're looking for tiny items or checking to see if something can be opened, it's just an exercise in frustration. The gameplay itself is balanced terribly against the survivors, which, again, could be made to work as a mood and atmosphere feature, but instead ends up making it so that the monster is guaranteed to win 90% of the time. This isn't helped by the fact that the person playing as the monster can hear what the others are saying in voice chat - you can't plan or talk to anyone without giving it away. What's the point of a voice chat if its main use is to inform the enemy of what you're doing?On top of everything else, the game is horribly optimised, and with its simple graphics, still manages to demand more processing power than, say, running Skyrim on ultimate settings, or Dragon Age Inquisition, or various other graphics-intensive games. I had some real hopes for this game and unfortunately was let down. I didn't even notice that it had gone to full release, just assumed that it was still in beta because of the many obvious issues and bugs with it. Bit sad that it turns out this is the "final" product we get instead.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 24, 2015
												Written for AbsoluteHell.netDamned is, at its core an asymmetrical multiplayer-only experience that contains some incredibly effective tension and dread as you and your group skulk through darkened corridors in hopes to avoid an onslaught of death at the hands of a malevolent supernatural being.Damned successfully taps into that primeval fear of 'what you can't see can kill you' as it will have you more paranoid than David Icke himself. Chiming grandfather clocks, whistling radiators, creaking doors, flickering lights and laughing jack-o-lanterns all play their part as you move cautiously through each of the eleven different environments hoping not to touch uglies with that thing that goes bump in the night.Each of these come in a variety of flavours - from abandoned Hospitals, Asylums, Hotels to Factories; all oozing with an eerie atmosphere that isn't seen nor felt in any other horror based multiplayer game. The scares and true terror rival that of any single-player experience you can have and the fact that it can do this with a multiplayer only game is truly an astounding achievement in and of itself.You control (in first-person) any one of four stereotype survivors found in a haunted house scenario, A Priest, School Jock, Scene-Girl or fabled black-guy-who-dies-first, each armed with only a flashlight and your dwindling nerves. Who you choose to play as, is completely arbitrary as no one survivor has any type of skill set or play style to help aid your team, as all players can equally carry any amount of keys, safe combinations and interact with the environment. As the Survivors, it is up to you to help your colleagues escape the nightmare you have found yourselves in by scouring through cupboards, desk drawers, iron safes and anything else, in order to search out your ways to freedom.On the opposite end of that spectrum sits one other player who is in control of the ghoul/ghost for any chosen scenario and their objective is to simply wipe out all survivors before they can reach the end, the unique twist is though, that the monsters come in three variations and each variant of ghoulish terror requires a different strategy to conquer and overcome as you (the survivor) cannot deal any damage or defeat this player in any way. I will break down the Survivors versus Monster like so:MARY (GHOST):Mary is a scary Asian ghost girl who has the ability to randomly teleport anywhere in the vicinity of the survivors, but not close enough to be within immediate visual range, this can be initiated either by the player or automatically if they spend too long searching for a victim. She can open doors, stalk the hallways slowly and calmly, sobbing with tears; the best strategy for survivors is to run the hell away because simply gazing directly at Mary or being too close in her proximity will trigger the hunter players ability to send her into a screaming rage, who will then run at you and eviscerate you from the inside out. Bar the doors and do not let her in. When she teleports, best to check behind you....LURKER (GHOUL):Looks a lot like Pumpkinhead or a really tall guy who decided that wearing his birthday suit was too much effort. This Ghoul can move between Spectral and Material realms much like Raziel from Soul Reaver, only with a cool down timer and while spectral, cannot see the survivors but can move at speed, pass through locked doors & rig sound traps so if someone stumbles past, say a grandfather clock then it will chime triggering the Ghoul to materialise and slowly, VERY slowly chase after the unlucky individual.PHANTOM (GHOST):Is omnipresent, this ghost can move through any locked door and drift around at terrifying speeds. The only way to avoid this one is to remain silent and move slowly through the level, keeping a visual on it at all times where possible. The only way it can detect a survivor is by sudden noise, such as turning the flashlight on and off or by getting too close to it, thereby lighting that survivor up in an aura that only then can the Phantom detect a presence, other than that it is essentially blind, but the hardest to compete against. Stay away from the centre of the rooms.If any of these creatures manage to catch you it is a one hit kill with no coming back and if you were the one carrying all the keys, you have just made everyone else’s day a whole lot worse.Now, not that I mean to end on the negatives but there are some issues that need to be addressed. Firstly, there are no dedicated servers as it is only a peer-to-peer service meaning that game sessions can range from stable to downright jittery with latency playing a big part of that problem. The game itself is already ill-optimized and framerates can differ heavily depending on what kind of hardware your rig is running. You can have a budget six core processor or a monster expensive processor, you will still see many of the same issues so I would feel terrible with anybody 'meeting' the actual specifications required to run this game as opposed to surpassing them and I mean, it is not exactly the most demanding game out there, regarding hardware requirements. It doesn't even LOOK all that spectacular to begin with. It absolutely is not horrible, but the fact it has issues, requires some serious attention from the Developers if they hope to iron out these flaws and beef up the stability of this product.The animations for all characters border between offensive and hilarious as many, if not all of them look like imposable action figures, with the bare basics required to call them 'high-poly' models. They portray little to no emotion, physically, the audio doing all the work it needs to do and thank christ there! Because when you are trudging through these dank environments which are so beautifully, crafted and rendered, to see John the Priest, complete with missile launching action, running out of a room then being chased by the Lurker who looks as stiff as super glued lego you cannot help but either smirk or run in the opposite direction terrified of either the animations or the monster chasing you at the forefront of it all. It pulls you almost straight out of the experience and the immersion of it all but not enough to justify it as truly terrible.With a little more time spent developing and fine-brushing some animations and textures, Damned can be a lot of things that many games are not and you can really sense the quality under its garbled hood. However, right now, there are a lot of things it is not and given a lack of content and game modes you really see all there is to see within the first ten to twenty minutes of playing. It is really only saved because with friends, it can be an absolute rioting good time full of scares, tension and laughter.Get this to experience it with friends, because finding a server where it is stable or the lobby leader will not kick you out come few and far between. Damned is an enjoyable if not, short lived package that deserves your support and with that, will with any luck come a much better game down the line.SCORE:[76/100]- Daniel Kerr Spendlove

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 24, 2015
												This one of the very few reviews I've written. I am annoyed enough to actually write one.A number of my friends and I acquired this game through a recent Humble Bundle, expecting a few hours' fun with what reads like a really nice idea for an asymmetric multiplayer game. What we got was a bug ridden, slowly performing, confusing mess across multiple different systems. Let me explain.The game has many problems, most obviously bugs: menus appearing unexpectedly and staying there throughout gameplay; unexpected freezing which forces a quit to menu or process kill; bizarre drops in mouse sensitivity or input tracking; variable framerates; disconnects from multiplayer games yet remaining in the player list; minimal feedback on player/monster actions; the list goes on. We were playing on a mixture of systems, some with NVidia cards and some with AMD, all using Windows 7, and I can say now that we've not had anywhere near as many problems with any other game. The next bunch of issues relate to the game design itself. The basic elements of the gameplay are there, but they seem to be at the level found in a lot of early version mods available for other games. Playing as any of the monsters is actually very shallow in terms of gameplay, and playing as the survivors doesn't really feel like anything beyond semi-coordinated trial and error. There's barely any interaction with levels beyond picking items up and opening doors, the latter of which has a needlessly awkward grab mechanic that in practice doesn't justify its existence. The items are difficult to spot as well, which results in the survivor's role rapidly becoming one of frustration and confusion, especially when playing a new level. As a group Damned sounded fun, and we play in a LAN environment so we hoped the horror aspect would make it a good investment. As it turns out the gameplay is barely fleshed out, and when the game does run it either runs very badly or encounters problems. I just can't recommend it, not with many other games offering much better for a lot less than the Steam price at the time of writing (£15).The worst bit? We experienced all the above in an hour. A single hour. It literally took 60 minutes to exhaust patience of five PC gamers who are happy to mod, tweak, upate drivers, and customise controls, in order to get something working. Did we give it enough time? You decide; we found something else to play.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
												A game that is fun with friends, and not much more. At least, when the game works is it fun. Joining a game with friends and making it work is the definition of frustrating. Some party members cannot join properly, causing the host to disband and recreate a party several times before getting a functioning game. After 10 minutes of unsucessful tries, when you finally get in game, it's an enjoyable experience. The game however, runs horribly, even on a GTX 970/i5-3570k I feel lucky to even getting 30 fps at times. Gameplay; finding keys and batteries just to see is definitely a horrifying experience; the ambience of the game is phenomenal. With any of the monsters chasing you, it's definitely a terrifying experience.  Spawning system is wonky and occasionally on several maps you're stuck searching for a key that just doesn't exist. The basic premise for the game is decent, it's a shame that the developer didn't expand on it any more than that. At a five dollar price point, if you and a couple friends want to have a devent spooky time, then I recommend it. At a higher price, I would not recommend it. The frustrations to get an enjoyable scary experience are just not worth it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
												First, let me state that I was following this game since Early Access, but waited for "Full Release."  I was exceedingly hopeful for this game.The reasons I CANNOT recommend this game are the following:It is horribly incomplete and one-dimensional.There is but one thing to do in the game: Run like a moron and hope you don't miss a vital key in a bucket or some crevice while the already-lethal ghost is chasing you down, clicking their mouse button til you get close enough for the kill shot to register.There is no depth to this game in regards to gameplay.  There are no complex objectives requiring any kind of cooperation among the players.  The monster/ghost role is as simple as just left clicking and holding down W.This game has so much potential, but I fear the developers aren't able to provide anything more than a short-lived atmospheric bore-fest.

content:
Posted: February 10, 2015
												I love the style of the game. It's horror meets escape-the-room; two of my favorite types. It's a bit like Amnesia, only you play as either the monster (one of 3 choices) trying to kill everyone, or one of four "survivors" trying to escape the place you're trapped in by collecting keys to unlock doors. A few problems with game bugs - getting stuck in walls, game disconnecting, dying sometimes produces two dead bodies or a live body running into a wall, but otherwise the game is playable and worth the $20 if they fix the bugs. Best played with a group of friends, in a dark room, with voice chat. Really adds to the creepiness, or hilarity (if you have friends like mine).
